Ottawa, August 24, 1939.

Dear Father Belleau:

I have for acknowledgment your telegram of August 23, in which you inform me that the Albany Residential School has been destroyed by fire.

It is gratifying to learn from your communication that no lives were lost and that a certain amount of furniture was saved. The receipt of the news of this fire is very disturbing to the officials of this Branch and to myself. There have been five fires at Indian residential schools since our 1939-40 estimates were prepared last fall. The Carcross Church of England Residential School was totally destroyed by fire and certain sections of other schools were damaged by fire and have to be rebuilt this year.

I note that it is your intention to rebuild the Albany school in the near future. I would suggest that before even the preliminary steps are taken toward the construction of a new school at Albany, the matter be carefully reviewed by you or representatives of your Church and the Minister and his officials here. In view of the large number of disastrous fires that took place last year at educational institutions in the province of Quebec and the number of fires at our own schools in recent months, I am of the opinion that Parliament will hesitate to vote per capita grants for the operation of residential schools in the future,

Reverend Henri Belleau, O.M.I.,
Moose Lake,
Ontario.
other than those that are of fireproof construction. The Government, in the construction of its own schools, has definitely decided that these buildings must be of fireproof construction throughout, and it is just possible that an attempt may be made to extend the same policy to the construction of church-owned schools. In any event, a conference such as the one I suggest will enable you to learn exactly the policy of the Government and will tend to prevent misunderstandings that might arise in the future.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Director.

Dear Sir:

All the laundry machinery in use at the Albany R.C. Indian Residential School was lost in the fire which destroyed the main school building.

A temporary building, measuring 75 by 35 has been erected and the children will be accommodated in it for the winter, and until such time as the new school is built.

I am informed that there are several out buildings that could be used as a laundry. Although funds in the Department are running very low, would it be possible for you to supply this school with at least a washing and drying machine. This would make the work of the staff much lighter during the intervening period. I hope that you will give this matter favorable consideration.

I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

As you are aware, the main building at the Fort Albany Indian Residential School was destroyed by fire on August 23rd last. This is the only Catholic school on the west coast of James Bay and during its life span an area in which there are over 800 Roman Catholic Indians.

It is absolutely necessary that this building be replaced immediately and the Oblate Order respectfully submits the following for your consideration:

1. That a fireproof building be erected costing in the neighbourhood of $60,000.00.

2. That $25,000.00 of this amount be provided in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41 and the balance in the fiscal year 1941-42.

3. Provided you agree to the request contained in paragraphs 1 and 2, the Oblate Order is ready to proceed in the summer of 1940 with the erection of this building following plans prepared by your architects. Every possible assistance will be given by the Oblate Order to keep the cost as low as possible.

4. On the completion of the payments requested in paragraph 2, the Oblate Order is prepared to turn over the new building together with the property and the out buildings to the Government without further remuneration.

In explanation of paragraph 4, I may say that this would include the following:

Ottawa, October 21, 1959.

For Construction of Albany Residential School

Dear Father Plourde,

I have for acknowledgment your letter of October 9th, in which you submit, for departmental consideration, certain specific proposals with respect to the rebuilding of the Albany Residential School.

I shall be glad to submit these proposals to the Minister for his consideration at the time the 1947-48 estimates are under review. In the meantime I am not in a position to state, however, what provision, if any, is likely to be made this year by the Government for the building of Indian residential schools. There are, as you know, two or three residential schools at this date in the process of construction. Provision will have to be made in next year's estimates for the completion and furnishing of these institutions.

In your letter you estimate that a fireproof school can be built at Albany at an approximate cost of $30,000. Our experience in the construction and reconstruction of residential schools in recent years would incline me to believe that the cost at Albany would substantially exceed the figure quoted by you. I have been wondering, therefore, if it would be possible for you to secure from someone familiar with construction costs an estimate of what in his judgment it would-

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st instant, in which you state that our proposals concerning the reconstruction of the Albany School will be submitted to the Minister.

We wish to thank you for so dealing with and promoting our work.

The estimated cost of a fire-proof building at Fort Albany was mentioned by us as approximately $60,000. Our estimate was based on the comparing conditions and rates prevalent in Keewatin and Manitoba, where two Catholic residential schools have recently been built, with conditions in James Bay.

The Sandy Bay school cost $40,000, and is a concrete fire-proof building consisting of two wings measuring respectively 60' by 30' and 60' by 30', having a basement and two storeys each added to the old building. Transportation to Sandy Bay is costly and everything in the nature of building material had to be brought from elsewhere.

At Fort Albany, we were intending to build, if the Department saw fit to approve, with stone available along the Albany River, a few miles away. However, the Albany Mission owns a seventeen-ton schooner; another schooner of twenty-five ton owned by the Oblate Order, will be available for transport.

The distance between Albany and Moosonee, as you well know, does not exceed ninety nautical miles, and the transport of building material will not amount to anything like the former rates which prevailed at the time of the erection of the school destroyed by fire.

We were induced also to estimate at about $60,000, the cost of a new school, because His Excellency Bishop LaJeunesse told us that $60,000 had been spent in the erection of a new school, in which case transport alone had cost $10,000. We believe
Ottawa, November 26, 1939.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Construction of residential schools at Albany, Ontario, and Carcross, Yukon.

I have for acknowledgment Mr. Bethune's memorandum of November 20, in which he seeks information with respect to representations that have been made to the Minister for the construction of the above noted schools.

In my memorandum to you dated November 21 I dealt with the construction of both these schools, together with four others, for the construction of which requests have been received from the church authorities by this Branch. There is little that can be added to the information supplied in that memorandum. If it is the intention of the Government to proceed next year with a building program, both the Carcross and the Albany schools have in my judgment a greater claim for consideration than any of the others. In view of the fact that the schools at these points were totally destroyed by fire during the last year, steps should be immediately taken to provide either Indian day or residential schools at both points. In view of the nomadic habits of the Indians in these districts, I cannot persuade myself that the construction of Indian day schools would meet the needs of the Indian population. I intimated in my memorandum of November 21 that the estimated cost of both these buildings would be approximately $185,700.

Director.

RAB
Ottawa,
December 8, 1939.

Dear Father Belleau:

Owing to conditions at the present time I am still unable to state definitely how much or how little will be provided for the erection of the Albany school. However, I was talking to the architect of the Surveys & Engineering Branch and he wants to have the plans prepared as far as possible so that in the event of money being made available we will be ready to start as soon as conditions permit. I would like very much to see you and if it is possible for you to come to Ottawa within the next week or so you might do so. If you call at my office I will take you over to see the architect.

I want it definitely understood, of course, that this action does not mean that the question of erecting a school at Albany has been definitely settled but only as stated above that we are trying to have everything prepared so that work can proceed if money is procured.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am in receipt of Mr. Jackson's memorandum of July 27, with reference to a requisition to purchase bricks for the Albany Indian Residential School.

As you are aware, this school was destroyed by fire in August, 1939. Last year His Lordship Rt. Rev. Henri Beilieu, O.M.I., advised the Department that the Church authorities were erecting a new building from missionary funds. There was no commitment on the part of this Department toward paying any of the costs of this building.

I attach, for your information, a picture of the building and I believe that a brick chimney is essential to eliminate fire hazard as far as possible. In view of the increasing costs of operation, I consider that it would be advisable for us to assist the Church in the erection of this chimney by supplying the bricks ordered on the requisition. Funds for the purpose are available in the current year's appropriation.

Ottawa, August 6, 1942.

MEMORANDUM:
Deputy Minister.

Mr. Jackson, in his memorandum of July 27, refers to a requisition for the purchase of bricks for the Albany Indian Residential School. A memorandum dated August 4 has gone forward to you on the particular matter of the requisition referred to.

This raises the whole question of our financial assistance to Church-owned schools.

In some cases the Branch supplies equipment or repairs, this being done through grants from appropriation. However, there have been instances where funds voted for repairs to present buildings have been used to assist in the construction of new buildings and thus our responsibility for the care for these affairs has increased. This phase of the matter is not satisfactory, in my opinion, as the practice is quite unsound. I would recommend that the matter be discussed fully when our new estimates are being determined, and that a definite decision be reached as to whether or not any money should be voted for this assistance.

Most of these schools are not fireproof and I would recommend the retention of the grant to pay for night watchmen, therefore, as by this means provision is made for the safety of the inmates which is a definite responsibility of the Branch.

Director.

Attention of Mr. L.W. McCutcheon.

Dear sir:

Answering your letter addressed to Rev. Bilodeau, O.M.I., Albany Indian Residential School and dated March 10, we inform you that the drums and cans containing paints and oil bought from Sherwin-Williams have never been returned for credit.

At this time of the year it is rather hard to get a quick answer from Albany due to poor means of travelling and communications but we imagine that these containers must have been used for several purposes as we always need things of all kinds in these remote and unorganized places. And so I think it would be their desire to keep these at the school even if they had to pay for them. Just advise what is to be done and we will conform to your will.

Sincerely yours,

Albany Residential School.

Re: The Rebuilding of the Albany School.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

The Albany School of my diocese was destroyed by fire in 1940, and due to the war and its demands on the finances of the Country, was not immediately rebuilt. However, plans for the new school were prepared by your architect Mr. Buck. I have these plans in my possession, and I must admit that every time I look at them, I become more and more anxious to see them put into execution.

At the present time, the building, serving the purpose of a Residential School, was erected by myself without any help from the Government, but it is a very temporary structure, too small to accommodate the number of Catholic children in the James Bay Agency that should attend school.

According to the 1939 Census figures, there are 1069 Indians of the Catholic Faith in that Agency and there is only one school for all their children. Catholics number 52% of the total Indian population, and if this figure of 52% is applied to the total number of school children on the whole Reserve, the figure obtained is 171. Therefore, the Albany School, even if a day school were established at Attawapiskat, would still serve about 140 children.

When the question of rebuilding this School is placed before Honorable Mr. Glen, the nomadic way of life of the Indians of the whole Reserve must be borne in mind, as day schools can certainly not be operated for Indian children whose parents are forced, by circumstances, to lead such a life.

2......
In making the above computation, I am obliged to use the 1939 Census figures, but I am sure that the 1945 Census will show closer to 200 children of school age in the James Bay Agency.

I confidently hope, therefore, that my request for the rebuilding of the Albany school, during the fiscal year 1946-1947, will be granted.

Yours very truly,

+ Henri Belleau
J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

My dear Bishop Belleau:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of December 10th, in which you discuss the desirability of establishing more adequate residential school accommodation at Albany.

It is just possible that we may make provision in the immediate future for a thorough educational survey of the Albany district, with the object of asking for the Parliamentary appropriation necessary to proceed with either an addition to the present school or a new school at this point.

Dear Sir:

Your letter dated Oct. the 5th., has been duly received.

The number of children authorized by the Dept. to be admitted to the Albany Residential School is 80 as a limit.

The number was complete before the last six arrived. Some came from Fort-Hope and the others were brought from Wenusk. In September, it is not very easy to travel as you know by experience, so we could not consider the possibility of sending those children back to their respective families. In fact, it was absolutely impossible to turn back those children from Wenusk. The family which came from Fort-Hope was so poor that it was also out of question to send them with their parents.

We accommodated them for the time being until we report the matter to the Department. As the school was already full to capacity I advised the Principal to enlarge the dormitories which enlargement should be completed by the first week in November.

I expect to be in Ottawa by the end of the Month and take the matter up with the Department, unless you would kindly bring the fact to the Department's attention, for which I would be very much obliged to you.

Dear Doctor,

Enclosed herewith are the report forms for the past quarter which I trust are satisfactory. Mrs Joselyn carried on in my absence. Thus school was not closed.

There is a matter I wish to draw to your attention. Three of Henry Rubens' children have been taken into the school here (R.C. school). You will recall assuring me that you would not permit such a thing to go on. Therefore I wish you would drop Fr Bilodeau a letter telling him that we do not want this kind of thing to go on. The result of this case is that others tell me that they will put their children in the school too as they cannot keep them. Thus you see the schools are going to become an ideal place for parents to put children they cannot keep. Wonderful outlook for the future!!!! Last winter the priest spent all his spare time over here asking my people if they wanted to go into hospital. As your records will show you he had great success even if the dept had to foot the bill. This winter I suppose it is going to be "open house" for school children. At any rate I am fed up with the antics of the R.C. church here. They do as they like apparently. Anyway I am not sitting idly by now watching them get what children they can.

Please advise me will you that you have written Bilodeau & then I will proceed to take the children out. We had a similar case I am told in Dr Hamilton's time & he very promptly turned the children out & made it plain that such tactics would not be tolerated. They need another reminder apparently.

I hear when in Moose you might have to make a trip through here but we have given up hope now but perhaps may see you this winter.

Sincerely yours

R.A. Joselyn

P.S. Should you come over you are quite welcome to stay with us. There is always a spare room. My wife sends kindest regards to Mr. Taylor.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, enclosing a letter received from Rev. R. A. Joselyn in connection with the admission of children to the Albany Indian Residential School.

In July, last, Rev. J. E. Saindon, O.M.I., wrote the Department stating that he had received a request for the admission of a number of non-Catholic Indian children to the Albany Residential School. In letter dated August 1st, the Department replied to Rev. Father Saindon as follows:

"I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, in which you advise that you have received a request from non-Catholic Indian families to admit their children to the Albany Residential School.

If the children to whom you refer are pagans, the Department is prepared to consider their admission to the Albany School, provided application forms are properly completed and forwarded to the Department, through the office of the Indian Agent, Dr. Tyer. If, however, the children to whom you refer are recognised as members of the Anglican or United Church, the Department could not consent to their admission to the Albany School, in view of Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act."

The Department has not received any applications for the admission of children to the Albany Residential School during the last six months and, consequently, we are not in a position to decide whether or not there are any children in the school who should not be there.

With reference to the second question contained in your recent letter, I may say that the Department does not approve of non-attending children residing in an Indian residential school.

Ottawa, January 29, 1936.

Rev. Sir:

In forwarding the September quarter return of the Albany Residential School, you requested the discharge of pupil No. 098, Jeannie D'Arcy Heas, and her discharge was approved by official letter of October 11th. The name of this girl now appears on the December quarter return, and grant is requested for her for 92 days.

Please let me know if she is still in the school, and, if so, why she was not discharged.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Dept. of Indian Education.

W. L. Tyner, Esq., M.D.,
Indian Agent,
Moose Factory,
Via Moosonee, Ont.
Monrovia, Feb 1936

Dear Mr. Tyner,

In fact, the discharge of the patient of Jeanne d'Arc Hospital no. 078 was asked and the notice of this demand was given on the day of discharge, her father having left Albany with her and we thought that she would not come back, but, in the meantime she came back and she was in the school.

Yours truly,

J H Bierman

Marguerite Sutherland Lucie Loutet

In comparing this return with the June quarter return, it is found that, on the June return, pupil #88 was shown as Raphael Okitikwurk, while the September return shows pupil #88 as Willie Sutherland. Please explain this.

The names of the under-mentioned children are shown on the September return but did not appear on the June return:

#007-G. Okimawimi #095-L. Noah #49-L. Eirington
#048-A. Sacum #37-M. Sutherland #56-G. Carpenter

Rev. A. R. Bilodeau, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Albany R. C. Indian Res. School,
Fort Albany,
via Moosonee, Ont.
The Department regrets that the quarterly returns from the Albany Residential School do not appear to be very carefully prepared and, especially in the case of the September return, it is almost impossible to check it as compared with the June return.

Please note that a new number should be given each pupil on first entrance to the school and this number should be dropped whenever a pupil is discharged.

The figure "O" should appear before the number of each girl. For instance, the first girl on the return should be shown as "016".

The names of the girls with the lowest register numbers should appear first on the return and the higher numbers should follow in consecutive order.

The names of the girls and the boys should be shown on separate forms, not on the same form.

The Department would appreciate if the above directions are carefully carried out in future when the quarterly return is being prepared. You will note on the back of the return full instructions with regard to the preparation of these returns.

The discharge of the pupils mentioned on the admission & discharge form is approved.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Albany, March 31, 1940

Dear Sir,

I acknowledge receipt of your letter 44-2-10 on March 23rd. The name of Alexandra Wesley, No. 0152, is not on the return for the quarter ended September, 1939, as you say. Looking through our records, we found this mistake; her name was written with the No. 0156 and so it should appear on that September return by mistake; the numbers were changed from 0152 to 0156. If really that name does not appear at all with any number, it was forgotten; the girl is still in the Albany Residential School, and her name will appear on the next return with the No. 0152. You would oblige me if you could let me know whether her name was on the September return with No. 0156, or not at all.

No. 071 M. Theresa Scott, No. 0116 Caroline Jakasum
= 072 Louise P. Martin = 80 Sapier Wesley
= 0105 Angele R. Martin

The above mentioned children have been absent from the school for some time and were readmitted last summer. The explanation is this: the James Bay West coast Indians are generally weak; and their children cannot stand more than three years the indoor life of the school at once. So after such a period of time, we allow them to go into the bush for a year or two; and then, if they are not above the age allowed by the Department, they come back.
Otherwise, it would do them some harm.

I have not sent to the Department the application forms for the new pupils, last summer, because we lost them in the fire of the school. I am sending you some new ones which cannot be signed by the parents who are away in the bush.

Yours truly,

Paul Langlois
Principal

The Dept. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Agnes Job, an Indian widow of Moose Factory Band, a member of your Church, has placed her boy, just 5 years old, at the Roman Catholic Boarding School at Albany in direct disobedience to advice given her. She wanted to send this boy to the Chaplean Boarding School in the idea that our Boarding School at Moose was filled to capacity, but it was not necessary that it be. Moose was filled to capacity, but it was not necessary that it should go to Chaplean because he could very conveniently attend the day school at his home in Moose, and she was told by the head master, Moose and by an local missionary,

It is subversive of all discipline and, of course, is also against the regulations of your Department that no Protestant child can be admitted to a Roman Catholic School and vice versa. There is also the consideration that if this boy were sent to Chaplean, it would add to the expense of your Department as well as to your church for travelling and other needs.

I therefore protest against the admission of that boy to the Albany Roman Catholic Boarding School, and request that he be sent home.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

John G. Moosonee
Ottawa, September 5, 1940.

Right Reverend Sir:

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Bishop Belleau:

I am very much worried over a report that has just been received from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. It appears that three pupils truanted from the Albany Indian Residential School last April and are presumably drowned.

The R.C.M.P. Police consider they should have been notified sooner, but it is doubtful if they could have done much in the matter at that time, in view of weather conditions. However, the Department should have been notified immediately. Any unusual event at a school, especially when the results are fatal, should be immediately brought to the Department's attention.

While I realize that there are difficulties that would be encountered, at the same time it is felt that a more determined effort should have been made by the Principal and staff to locate these boys. This whole happening is likely to have a very disturbing effect on the Indians and will naturally react on the school. I feel it advisable to recommend to you that very strict instructions be issued to the Principals of the residential schools in your diocese, to the effect that when any pupil truants from the school immediate and effective efforts should be made to locate the pupil.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

**CANADA**
Lake St-Ann December 20th, 1942

Doctor Thomas Orford,
MooseFactory.

Dear Sir,

You will notice in the quarterly return that Solomon William has not been very long in the school last fall. The reason is that the mother is not doing her part to help in keeping the boy in the school. That boy did not want to accept any remark from the sister. So one day, he started to fight with another boy; the sister stopped them and told Solomon who had begun not to do it any more. He did not like it and quit the school. I went to his home and took him back to the school; I had been waiting to see if the mother would send him back herself; but she did not.

A few days after again, he was not doing well in the refectory and the sister told him to keep quiet; but he refused and when he was outside for recreation, he quit again. I waited, but the mother did retain him. So I let him out. That boy has changed very much in his character during the year he spent in the bush.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

P. Langlois

Doctor Thomas J. Orford,
Indian Agent,
Moosonee.

Dear Sir,

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 28th ultimo, the Department approves the admission of Suzanne Okimawinew to the Albany Residential School for the period of one year.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. J. Leguerrier, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Albany Indian Res. School,
Fort Albany, via Moosonee, Ont.

Memorandum for Deputy Minister

Attached are applications for the admission of Andrew Wesley age seven and George Wesley age ten of the Albany Band in the Province of Ontario to the Albany (R.C.) Indian Residential School.

The applications state that the religious denomination is Roman Catholic. Superintendent J.S. Allan has approved these applications by signing them and by so doing verified the accuracy of the information shown thereon.

On receipt of these applications the Superintendent of Education advised Mr. Allan approving the admission of the two children to the Albany Indian Residential School. The two children were admitted to the Albany school on September 20th.

On March 29th we received a telegram from Bishop Neville R. Clarke reading as follows:

"Reverend Elliott of Albany advises Two Children of Joel Wesley Albany 293 Anglicans Are Enrolled in the Roman Catholic Residential School at Albany Please Arrange Discharge or Transfer to Moose Fort School"

On March 27th Right Reverend Neville R. Clarke confirmed his telegram with a letter a copy of which is attached.

On receipt of Bishop Clarke's protest the matter was immediately referred to Mr. Allan and he was requested to report fully on this situation.

We have now received a reply from Mr. Allan which reads as follows:

"I am in receipt of a letter from Bishop N.R. Clarke re the admission of George Wesley and Bertie Andrew Wesley into the R.C. Residential School at Albany.

This is the case of a mixed marriage, the father being Anglican and the mother Roman Catholic. According to the Indian Act the admission can be signed by either parent and according to the Roman Catholic Church, here, the children of mixed marriages are considered as belonging to their faith. I cannot recall who signed the application for admission but as this application was signed there is not much that can be done from this end in the form of a protest and I am afraid we do not have the answer to these problems at this end".

It would be appreciated if a ruling were given on these applications.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Attached are applications for the admission of Andrew Wesley age seven and George Wesley age ten of the Albany Band in the Province of Ontario to the Albany (R.C.) Indian Residential School.

It will be noted that the applications were signed by the father and the signature of the Indian Superintendent approved the information contained on them.

On receipt of these applications the Superintendent of Education approved the admission of the two children to the Albany Indian Residential School and they were admitted to the Albany (R.C.) school on September 20, 1951.

On March 29th we received a telegram from Bishop Neville R. Clarke reading as follows:

"Reverend Elliott of Albany Advises Two Children of Joel Wesley Albany 293 Anglicans Are Enrolled in the Roman Catholic Residential School at Albany Please Arrange Discharge of Transfer to Moose Fort School."

On March 27th Right Reverend Neville R. Clarke confirmed his telegram with a letter, a copy of which is attached.

On receipt of Bishop Clarke's protest the matter was immediately referred to Mr. Allan and he was requested to report fully on this situation.

We have now received a reply from Mr. Allan which reads as follows:
"I am in receipt of a letter re the admission of George Wesley and Bertie Andrew Wesley into the Roman Catholic Residential School at Albany.

This is the case of a mixed marriage, the father being Anglican and the mother Roman Catholic. According to the Indian Act the admission can be signed by either parent and according to the Roman Catholic Church, here, the children of mixed marriages are considered as belonging to their faith. I cannot recall who signed the application for admission but as this application was signed there is not much that can be done from this end in the form of a protest and I am afraid we do not have the answer to these problems at this end".

It would be appreciated if a ruling were given on these applications.

Director."
Ottawa, May 5, 1952.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

I desire to refer to my memorandum of May 1st, with regard to the applications for the admission of Andrew Wesley and George Wesley to the Albany R.C. Indian Residential School.

Right Reverend Neville Clarke, Suffragan Bishop of Moosejaw, who has protested the admission of these children to the Albany School, telephoned to me this morning from Toronto in regard to the matter.

Bishop Clarke stated that the father, Joel Wesley, has been married three times. His first wife was a Roman Catholic and his second and third wives were members of the Church of England. He stated that Joel Wesley has always been recognized as a member of the Church of England. Bishop Clarke further stated that the two boys are children of Joel Wesley's second marriage.

The information just supplied by Bishop Clarke is different from that contained in Indian Superintendent Allan's letter which was quoted in my memorandum of May 1st.

In view of the above, I feel that your decision should be withheld until we obtain further information from the Indian Superintendent.

Director.

I agree with you that any further decision should be taken only after we are in full possession of the facts. I understand that you have asked the Indian Superintendent to let you have a report on this case.

November 13, 1952

Mr. J.S. Allan,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Moose Factory, Ont.

With reference to your letter of November 3rd regarding the admission of Charlotte Kibokse and Emilda Okitiko to the Albany Indian Residential School, it is noted that the first girl is seventeen years of age and the latter twenty years of age.

Your letter is not clear as to why you consider that institutional care is required for these girls. It would be appreciated if you would obtain more information as to the reason why these girls can not obtain employment rather than attend school. It can be readily understood that as these girls have never attended school they would not adapt themselves to classroom activities as it would be necessary for the teacher to place them with a group of youngsters who are taking Grade 1. We are disallowing the Per Capita Grant claimed for these girls on the September Return.

Philip Phelan,

Honourable Sir:

I have asked my good friend and compatriot, Canon H.G. Cook of the Indian School Administration, Ottawa, to lodge a protest in my name regarding the petition of the Roman Catholic Bishop of Moosonee to have one of our Anglican children placed in the Roman Catholic School at Fort George.

This case is a very lengthy one, and Supt. J.S. Allen is submitting a full report to Dr. MacKay Director of Indian Affairs Branch. You will be able to obtain all the details there.

However I will give you a short resume of the case. The mother Naomi George was hospitalized with a T.B. in 1949 being brought down from Fort George. She was put in the R.C. hospital over my strong objections as one of the reasons for her leaving as the request of her people to do so to avoid the pressure being put on her at Fort George. In April 1950 she wrote asking that she be moved to the Anglican hospital owing to proselytizing by the R.C. priest. I contacted Dr. E.P. Moore and an investigation was ordered. My claims were substantiated and the woman was ordered moved, but as the local doctor gave her such a short time to live, it was decided to leave her there. She has outlived medical prophecy, and is still alive, and has been converted, as I maintain under pressure.

Now this woman is not mentally nor physically normal, she has been under the influence drugs for the medical two years her condition is so serious.
The petition is made by the Roman Bishop under section 117 of the Indian Act. This I feel cannot be considered owing to the mother's condition. Also the child ten years of age is at present being detained against her will. She entered the hospital in company with the Principal Canon H.S. Shepherd of our school, for the sole purpose of visiting her mother. The request being made by Sister Roland that, the child be allowed to visit her mother who is on her death bed, a very unpleasant scene occurred as reported by Canon Shepherd and the child was returned.

The Church of England closed its hospitals on James Bay to co-operate with the Govt. and assist in making the Govt. hospital at Moose-Factory a real asset. The Romans took the exact opposite course, and today a building new hospitals. So we cannot be expected to accept such actions as the above without protest.

Trusting this will receive your attention, and thanking you for your kindness,

Yours sincerely,
"Neville R. Clarke"

Dear Sir,

Re: Alice George

Sometime in July, last month, I received a letter from Father Couture at Fort George regarding the above mentioned Alice George, then in residence in our School at Fort George, requesting that she be allowed to go to Moosonee on their boat to visit her mother who was ill in their hospital and not expected to live. I answered this letter stating that if he would give me a promise that Alice would be returned to our school at Fort George before the date of school opening in August, that I would allow her to go. He did not give me any such promise and Alice did not go.

Sometime after, I had a letter from Sister Rollande at Fort George saying that she had promised to bring Alice from Fort George to Moosonee and would I please see that Alice was put on the plane with Sister Rollande. I asked the same promise of Sister Rollande as of Father Couture and Sister Rollande would give me no promise that Alice would be returned to Fort George. I refused to allow Alice to go with Sister Rollande.

I told Sister Rollande that since I was then about to move from Fort George to the Bishop Gordon Memorial School at Moose Factory, that I would get in touch with the Indian Agent at Moose Factory and if he, Mr. Allan, would authorize it, I would bring Alice with me to Moose Factory and take her myself to visit her mother. The Indian Agent gave permission and I brought Alice to Moose Factory on Saturday, August 9th, 1952.

Yesterday, August 11th, I took Alice to visit her mother at the Roman Catholic Hospital Moosonee. I had with me besides Alice, an interpreter, because I wanted to be clearly understood by Naomi, Alice's mother, who is a Cree Indian and understands no English, and further I wanted to know exactly what Naomi had to say.
We were admitted to the Hospital, but asked to wait for some considerable time before being allowed to see Naomi George, Alice's mother. When we were admitted to the patient's room, which contained one other patient besides Naomi George, Father Couture of Fort George, another Priest, possibly resident at Moosonee, and two sisters were in the room and remained there for as long as I stayed.

After Alice had had a reasonable length of time with her mother, I explained to Naomi through my interpreter, that I would have to take Alice back to Moose Factory, but that I would bring Alice again to see her and possibly several times before I needed to take her back to our school at Fort George. I then asked Alice to come, which she proceeded to do, without any hesitation. Alice was then caught by her mother and there ensued a most unpleasant scene of Alice trying to free herself to get to me and her mother trying to restrain her. It would have been easy to have forced Alice from her mother, who is a person very ill, but that I would not do. No force was exerted by anyone except that of Alice trying to free herself from her mother and her mother's effort to restrain her. All the time Alice was crying violently. After some minutes, I decided it was inhuman to allow the struggle to continue and so I left Alice, much to her distress, but with the promise, that I would not forget her but would see that the right things was done concerning her.

Naomi George was a member of the Church of England when Alice was placed in the school at Fort George. At the time of the proposed visit Alice had no clear remembrance of her mother, nor any desire to see her. Alice is now ten years of age and has spent four year's in our school at Fort George, a member of our happy school family, quite content and making excellent progress. It was quite clear that the child was greatly distressed yesterday by being kept away from me, and that the child's desire and happiness would be to return to me and to my care.

I would recommend that Alice be placed back in my care, be kept at Moose Factory, if Alice desires it, and allowed to visit her mother under normal and happily conditions, for the period Naomi might yet live and at the end of that time, return to her people and home environment at Fort George.

Faithfully submitted,

(SGD.) H.S.Shepherd

Rev. T. Masson brought a matter to mine attention on my return from up the coast. Alice George from the Anglican residential school at Fort George is at present in Moosonee. Shepherd, dated 29/7/52, was refused the privilege of even seeing the girl in a pastoral capacity. Also I am informed application has been made to have this girl transferred to the R.C. School at Fort George under Sec. 117 of the Indian Act.

Although you are well acquainted with the facts I will review them briefly. Naomi George was brought from Fort George by Dr. B. H. Harper, and was placed at Moosonee instead of in the Bishop Newnham Hospital at Moose Factory upon the direction of Dr. Harper who claimed an over-crowded condition existed in our hospital. Objections were made to you, but you rightly felt you could do little against medical advice. Naomi George xxx herself at that time expressed a desire to remain with her own people. As this was the definite wish of her husband now deceased.

In the winter of 49-50 I noticed evidences of proselytizing and along with letters from Daisy Ackynia, made request that in view of such evidences they be removed.

Daisy was transferred over to Moose Factory but again it was stated by Dr. Harper that moving Naomi might bring about her death. Later in the year along with the Rev. Wm. H. Thompson I visited the R.C. hospital where we were told she had turned to the Church of Rome. I immediately telephoned Dr. E.P. Moore who was in conference with Mr. F. Matters in North Bay, an immediate investigation was promised. Rev. Thompson visited Naomi all signs of her turning had vanished and she received Communion.

Now this woman has been at death's door ever since she came down from Fort George, and I leave it up to medical evidence whether or not she was entirely of a healthy mind and body. You have the evidences of Daisy's claims to whether there was any pressure being applied.
I would suggest that, though this child nor this mother be deprived of what little consolation remains for the mother in life. This should not be allowed to be another opportunity for proselytizing. I don't think in Canada, in our wildest imaginations can we find justifications for such actions.

I feel that if you find it impossible to deal with this, and I thank you for your previous fairness and considerations. The only course is to have this dealt with at the Meetings of the House of Bishops meeting in London and give it a public airing.

I am in receipt of a letter from the Rt. Rev. N.R. Clarke, Suffragan Bishop of Moosonee, copy of which is attached, protesting against the conversion of Naomi George to the Roman Catholic Faith and the entrance of the daughter to the Roman Catholic Residential School at Fort George.

Bishop Clarke called at my office and discussed the matter with me at length, protesting, most bitterly against the method of forceful actions of the Priests and nurses towards adherents of the Anglican Faith who are admitted into Roman Catholic Institutions in this Agency.

There are two cases to which Bishop Clarke makes special reference, viz., Daisy Atsynia, Old Factory Band No. 69 and Naomi George, Great Whale Band No. 8. Protest was made by him to me during the winter of 1949.

I will take each case separately and will deal with Naomi George, and without favoring either, I will describe her case since this matter was first drawn to my attention, without judgment or favor.

During the summer of 1949, I was visiting the Roman Catholic Hospital at Fort George, and was in semi-private room in which Naomi George was a patient. She requested Bishop Belleau, Vicar Apostolic of James Bay to interpret on her behalf. She explained, through his Excellency, that she was doing well and as I was going through to Richmond Gulf, she would be glad if I would bring her daughter back with me to Fort George for a visit and place her in school where she would be near her.
During my stay at Richmond Gulf, I called upon the family of Naomi George, conveying her message, and the suggestion of moving the child to Fort George was violently protested on the grounds that they had received word from her mother that the people in the Hospital were interfering with her religion. They demanded that Naomi be removed from the Hospital at Fort George and be transferred to Nursing Station at that point. Dr. Simpson, Regional Superintendent, Indian Health Services, was at Fort George upon my return and the reported proselytizing, of which there was no evidence, was discussed. The question of transferring this woman to the Nursing Station was also considered, but due to the fact that this building was much overcrowded the idea was abandoned. It was then decided that she be moved to Moose Factory during the winter.

In the early part of the month of March, 1950, this woman along with Daisy Atsynia, Old Factory Band No. 69 was transferred to Moosonee and complaints were being registered within one month of admission to the R.C. Mission Hospital at Moosonee, to the then Ven. N.R. Clarke. First complaint was registered April 3rd, by Daisy Hester, cousin of Daisy Atsynia and this continued until I transferred this woman to Bishop Newham Hospital 24th May, 1950. This transfer was in full agreement with Bishop Belleau, who expressed the desire that anyone who was not happy in the hospital, it would be in their own interests to have them removed.

The case of Naomi George was thoroughly discussed with Dr. Cronk, who, due to her critical condition, advised against moving her. She required special care and treatment which could not be rendered in the Bishop Newham Hospital. Her condition was also discussed with Archdeacon Clarke, who had no other wish than that she have her last few days in peace and agreed that she remain where she was.

For your information and perusal, I am attaching copies of all letters from this file.

During the month of April this case was thoroughly discussed with Mr. Matters, Regional Supervisor in North Bay, who took the file through to Ottawa for discussion.

This case has again burst forth with very strong protests from the Rt. Rev. N.R. Clarke, Anglican Bishop of Moosonee, upon the proposed transfer of Alice George, daughter of Naomi, (who I am informed was received into the Roman Catholic Church on October 30, 1950, the ceremony has been registered at the Roman Catholic Mission, Moosonee,) being transferred to Fort George R.C. School.
I am attaching copies of all correspondence for your own information and judgment and will appreciate having your comments and direction with regard to the two children of Naomi George, viz., Charlotte and Alice.

Due to the dispute regarding the admission of this child into the Roman Catholic School, and religious denomination not being shown, Form No. I-A406, has not been completed. Bishop Beilieu advises that child Alice George has been admitted to the R.C. Indian Residential School at Fort Albany which is in full agreement with the mother.

Soon after her admission into the Church in 1950, I advised Mr. Allen verbally. In February 1952, Mrs. Naomi George signed the usual Application Form for admission of her daughter Alice, age 10, to the Roman Catholic Residential School at Fort George, P.Q. This application was shown to Mr. Allen with this comment: "When the school year is ended, I shall request that Alice's admission to the Roman Catholic School be approved by the Department." At that time, Mr. Allen expressed a view that Alice's admission would be approved by the Department.

I then gave official notice by letter, of Mrs. George's admission into the Church to Mr. Allen, (July 1952).

I also wish to state that I had previously requested that Mr. Allen make provision for Alice to come from Fort George to see her mother at the Moosonee Hospital. He answered that he would notify the Very Reverend Canon Shepherd, by radio. Canon Shepherd brought Alice to Moosonee in August 1952; while Alice visited her mother, Mrs. George decided to request the admission of her daughter to Fort Albany R.C. School, instead of the Fort George R.C. The Application Form was amended accordingly and given to Mr. Allen for his signature.

Mr. Allen forwarded this application, however, without his signature to Mr. Phelan, who returned it to him; Mr. Phelan states that Mr. Allen had not as yet re-sent the form back to Ottawa. Meanwhile, we decided to send Alice to Fort Albany R.C. School.

Then on September 19th, your Department sent a wire to Mr. Allen ordering the return of Alice to the Fort George Church of England School, pending an investigation and a final decision on the case.

I regret that the required information on Alice's case has not yet been transmitted to the Department by Mr. Allen. Had you been informed of all the pertinent facts, this present situation would not have arisen.
I feel that Mrs. George's right to have her daughter Alice, educated in a Roman Catholic School is clear, according to Section 117 of the Indian Act.

As requested when in Ottawa recently, I carried out an investigation as to the circumstances of the above case, which involved a change in religion and the transfer of a child from the Fort George Anglican Residential School to the Albany Roman Catholic Residential School.

Mrs. George is presently in the Roman Catholic Hospital at Moosonee. The circumstances covering her arrival there are covered in the report of Mr. Allan.

All through the case reference is made to her being in a dying condition, this from three years ago. For this reason, it was suggested that I should have a doctor accompany me when I interviewed her. On my arrival at Moose Factory, I found that the two doctors who had been attending her were absent and Dr. McKee did not feel that he could give any report as to her condition either by a single examination or by being present at the interview. I, therefore, visited her accompanied only by an interpreter.

There was another Indian patient in the room, at first the Sister, who is the nurse, wanted to stay but acceded to my request that she leave the room.

I found Mrs. George to be bright and to my lay mind quite alert. Had I not known of her long stay in hospital, I would have said that she was not very ill. After chatting for a while to relieve her of any tension and explaining why I wanted to speak to her, I asked why she had
decided to change her religion. The answer was that it was from what she had seen in the hospital and that no influence had been used on her to change. This latter remark was rather surprising as no mention had been made of influence and Indian women especially very seldom volunteer statements.

When asked if the child Alice had been happy at the Fort George Anglican School, she said that Alice was happy there. With regard to the change to Albany Roman Catholic School, she said that she did not know beforehand that the girl was going there but she was quite satisfied with the arrangement. She further said that she had had letters from Alice that she was happy to be there.

Whilst there was much more conversation of a general nature intended to engender confidence to talk freely, these answers covered the main points we wanted to clear up. I had no difficulty in seeing her at least semi privately.

The next day, October 15th, I interviewed the Rev. Canon Shepherd at the Moose Factory Indian Residential School. He outlined what had happened in the same way as is done in the letters from he and Mr. Allan. The only new points he mentioned were that when Mrs. George was in the Fort George Roman Catholic Hospital, he had no difficulty when visiting her or seeing Alice. He had known her for a long time and she was always friendly. When he visited her at Moosonee, he could not see her privately and with the other people in the room, she refused to even shake hands with him. This he claimed could only be due to something that Mrs. George had been told at Moosonee.

I do not think that this case involves any opinions from me. I simply tried to get answers to questions on certain points, verified as far as possible that the statements made in the previous correspondence had been made by the persons concerned. All the Indians concerned in the correspondence were away from Moosonee. Most of them live at Fort George and were visiting Moose Factory at different times. I will be glad to try to enlarge on any point of which I have knowledge if you so desire. As I see it, the case is simply the matter of religious denominations and how the change affects children already admitted to school in proper form.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Dear Bishop Belleau:

I am very much worried over a report that has just been received from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. It appears that three pupils truanted from the Albany Indian Residential School last April and are presumably drowned.

The R.C.M. Police consider they should have been notified sooner, but it is doubtful if they could have done much in the matter at that time, in view of weather conditions. However, the Department should have been notified immediately. Any unusual event at a school, especially when the results are fatal, should be immediately brought to the Department's attention.

While I realize that there are difficulties that would be encountered, at the same time it is felt that a more determined effort should have been made by the Principal and staff to locate these boys. This whole happening is likely to have a very disturbing effect on the Indians and will materially react on the school. I feel it advisable to recommend to you that very strict instructions be issued to the Principals of the residential schools in your diocese, to the effect that when any pupil truants from the school immediate and effective efforts should be made to locate the pupil.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,

Lake Ste-Anne June 14th, 1941

Report on the death of three boys of our Lake Ste-Anne School, at Albany, James Bay.

Names:
John Koki, 14 years old, from Attawapiskat,
Michel Sutherland, 15 years old, from Moosonee,
Michel Matinas, 11 years old, from Attawapiskat.

Statement on each child:
John Koki: He had been accepted last year only after he had promised to be quiet, obedient and respectful. He had already been three years in the school and had not given much satisfaction to the members of the staff. He was hard to control.

Michel Sutherland: He was in his second year at school. We have to complain about him.

Michel Matinas: He was in his first year at school and we had nothing to complain about him too.

The facts:
In the night from Friday, 18th of April, to Saturday 19th, the boys escaped from the dormitory early in the night and went away; and we are without news from them ever since.

What was done to find them:
In the morning when we noticed these children had escaped, we thought they had been going into the bush around here so we waited till the middle of the afternoon, hoping they would be back in the evening; because when some do get away in daytime, they come back at least in the evening.

Also, we built two camps where the children prefer to hide in the winter time. So we sent an Indian to visit those camps and walk in the bush around here; the Brothers also walked in different directions, but they did not find them.

Nearly all the Indians were away for hunting. On Sunday, they were reported to have been seen at a small distance near here; so the Indians went, but found only tracks that he followed till dark, and then he cut. These tracks were leading to the North (Indian's Bay) Co.

On Monday morning, our team got back from Moosonee; the trip had been bad; so we let the dogs rest that day.

During that time, we inquired among the children and the result was this:
John Koki was the chief of the band. He gave reason for his escape that he wanted to go back to Attawapiskat to see his mother. He had asked his former brother and many other boys to go away with him; they all refused; and like young men, neither answered "I will not go out" nor are well treated here and I like to be at school." At last he found two with whom he went.

The head teacher said: "I am going to give the children slices of bread every hour between meals, in the morning and in the afternoon, in a few days, when they left, they started to hide those slices of bread they were given. John Koki had also his bow and arrows, and he was reported by his brothers to have said: 'I don't need food; I can take much grub; I have my arrows and I will kill something to eat.'"

We did not notice that they had stolen anything like axes or food before they left.

On Tuesday morning, I sent to the south of North River, a Father with an Indian and the dogs; but they did not find them and came back just in time in the afternoon; if they had turned back two hours later, they would have been caught by the break-up which took place that same afternoon. After that, we could not do anything to find these children.

Then the Indians were back after the breakup of the ice; they reported he had seen a small wigwam and arrows on the south shore of Moosonee River, about twenty miles from here. I sent five men to look for the bodies, but they did not find any.

So the children might have been able to cross the river on the thin ice; they broke through and the current carried them out into the Bay.

The parents have notified.

Paul Lanklois O.M.I., Principal

As soon as the boys had gone, contact was made with the Attawapiskat Mission by wireless, and the Father in charge of the latter notified the father of the leader of the truants. This Indian immediately set off for Albany. The break-up of the ice was earlier at Attawapiskat than at Albany. As no further news had been heard from the man, it was believed that he might have already found the three boys. An accident had happened to him and he had given up the search. It had then become utterly impossible to continue looking for the truants, because of the break-up of the ice on the Albany River. In fact, only three full days elapsed between the departure of the boys and the breaking of the ice. Conditions of broken ice, jammed and varying at times make traveling impossible or across any river. This and only this was the real cause of the loss of the three boys.

On arriving in Albany and learning with all evidence that all hope was no more, Charlie Kioki and his wife, parents of the leader of the truants showed not the least attitude of regret toward the Father Principal. No word was uttered by them against the Staff of the School, but they burst into tears and with great spirit of faith, loudly spoke us God words of deep resignation. The opposite might have been expected from them at the time. You will please find enclosed a translation of the letter they sent to the Father in charge of Attawapiskat. A similar letter was sent to the Principal of the School.

The desertion of the truants had not even a shadow of reason and they had received no punishment to cause them discontent. Moreover, the time of their departure (three days only before the breaking of the ice) made the members of the Staff easily believe the three boys had not gone any distance, and consequently, to search within a radius of a few miles, the first and second day.

I frankly confess that I cannot understand how any accusation of negligence could be substantiated against the Father Principal of the School.

I thank you very sincerely for the interest you take in the welfare of the Indians, concerning their education; Thank you also for the advice you have given in your letter concerning situations and occurrences like those of last April.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter no. 44-2-1, dated 17th instant, regarding the loss of three truant pupils of the Albany Indian Residential School. I am enclosing a copy of the report made by the Reverend Father Principal of the school to Constable Dexter of the RCMP Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

The Father Principal had transmitted a message by wireless to our Moosonee Mission in order that I should notify you. He thought at the time that details would not be necessary in the message. Unfortunately, I was somewhat puzzled by the lack of details and put off until later when further particulars could be obtained. I now realize that the very scant information concerning the loss of the boys should have been forwarded to you; in this, I readily admit that I was wrong, because it was difficult to get a lengthy and complete report on the affair before June. The message sent by the Reverend Father Principal over the radio was transmitted soon after the escape of the boys.

As for notifying the RCMP Police, we could see no use in doing this soon. I am still of that opinion; nothing in the way of rounding up the truants could have been done by them because the Police are stationed in Moose Factory, over a hundred miles away; and moreover, a plane could not make a landing at the time because the ice on the lake was just about breaking. There was no open water where a plane could have landed. The Albany School dog sled was used to bring back from Moosonee at the time, and the early thaw obliged the Father and his Indian guide to take weeks over a week to cover the distance, traveling in water and over dangerous ice. Help from Moosonee or elsewhere was therefore out of question.

The truants knew that their chances of desertion were better in the absence of the Mission's dogs. As soon as the exhausted dogs had been given a rest, another Father set off with an Indian in pursuit of the fugitives. It was considered too risky in so doing. After a fruitless run of nearly twenty miles, they had to return; but they did so just in time. Two hours after they had left the North Branch of the Albany River (about fifteen miles from the School) the break-up of the ice occurred. They had to wade in water well over their knees in certain dangerous passages.

You state "that it is felt that more determined effort should have been made by the principal and staff to locate these boys."

The Father Principal himself was confined to the hospital for a severe illness at the time of the evasion. Nevertheless, it being during the night of the 18th-19th April that the boys escaped, the search for them began on the 19th. Translation of the letter written by the same to Albert Matinas.

"Letter of consolation:

"My friends whom I love and with whom I share suffering, I wish to console you although I suffer from anguish myself; but wishing to show you that I love you, being at heart (i.e., feeling as you feel) exactly as you are, I beseech you to accept as I do, this suffering, I wishing to accept it with meekness for the sake of God. For God Himself is the one who will judge us with mercy, let us accept our suffering to please God. Let us hope that the bodies may rise again, just as we lost them and let us be consoled by the fact that the body dies only once in this world (on earth). Let us do as God wants us to do, in order to redeem those who are the worst sinners and to redeem ourselves, and to not lose these our children in the next life. If we try to please God in this suffering which He gives us, the heaviest, which He has chosen for us, let us thank Him feeling how much He loves us; and let us listen one to the other with pité when we who suffer this suffering for the first time.

"My friends, that is how I accept this suffering given us by God. I cannot go to see you. Their is only one road, I think, the one which leads to the church; that is the only way that I am able to walk.

From this happening, I do not wish that rash judgment arise, so that (in turn) we be rashly judged. Always, as much as we could, we minded our children well. But to them it happened just as God willed (thought), I don't wish that judgment arise from this about my child who is already without life. But I only wish that search be well made for the bodies that they may be buried, if they are now lying in the wilderness. Not that anger arises; I suffer more when I hear that this was taken with resistance (without resignation). I listened patiently to the news told to me about the event at Lake Ste-Anne (Site of the Albany School). One thing only did I detect, everybody saying that Father Paul (who was then the missionary who was the Father in charge of the School). When I heard this, I went to tell God our Father all that I thought and he was glad to hear it. Above all, I am sorry for you whom I love and who are religious people (the writer here seems to address the missionaries) and who are also about to be judged, it being without reason that you be judged, as it is without reason that God be judged. He who is God Himself! It seems to suffer rebellion in such a case.

"Do not think that I alone or both Charlie (her husband) and I will join in this if it is done (that any judgment be passed on the other parties). I will not give myself up to rebel against God who loves me.

"I cannot speak long, but I have written this letter wishing to state well what I think."

(This letter is from Agnes, wife of Charlie Kicki, of Attawapiskat.)

Dear Bishop Belleau,

I am very much worried over a report that has just been received from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. It appears that three pupils truanted from the Albany Indian Residential School last April and are presumably drowned.

The R.C.M.P. consider they should have been notified sooner, but it is doubtful if they could have done much in the matter at that time, in view of weather conditions. However, the Department should have been notified immediately. Any unusual event at a school, especially when the results are fatal, should be immediately brought to the Department's attention.

While I realize that there are difficulties that would be encountered, at the same time it is felt that a more determined effort should have been made by the Principal and staff to locate these boys. This whole happening is likely to have a very disturbing effect on the Indians and will naturally react on the school. I feel it advisable to recommend to you that very strict instructions be issued to the Principals of the residential schools in your diocese, to the effect that when any pupil truants from the school immediate and effective efforts should be made to locate the pupil.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Report on the death of three boys of our Lake Ste-Anne School,
at Albany, James Bay.

Names:
John Kicki, 14 years old, from Attawapiskat,
Michel Sutherland, 13 years old, from Wooniek
Michel Matinas, 11 years old, from Attawapiskat.

Statement on each child:

John Kicki - He had been accepted, last year, only after he had promised to be quiet, obedient and respectful. He had already been three years in the school and had not given much satisfaction to the members of the staff. He was hard to control.

Michel Sutherland - He was in his second year at school. We have nothing to complain about him.

Michel Matinas - He was in his first year at school and we have nothing to complain about him too.

The facts:
In the night from Friday, 18th of April to Saturday 19th, the boys escaped from the dormitory, early in the night, and went away; and we are without news from them ever since.

What was done to find them:
In the morning, when we noticed those children had escaped we thought they had been going into the bush around here; so we waited till the middle of the afternoon, hoping they would be back in the evening; because when some do get away in daytime, they come back at least in the evening.

Also, we have built two camps, where the children go for picnics in the winter time. So we sent an Indian to visit those camps and walk in the bush around here; The Brothers also walked in different directions, but they did not find them.

Nearly all the Indians were away for hunting. On Sunday, they were reported to have been seen at a small distance from here; so the Indian went, but found only tracks that he followed till dark, and then he quit. Those tracks were leading to the Post (Hudson's Bay Co.).

On Monday Morning, our team got back from Moosonee; the trip had been bad; so we let the dogs rest that day. During that time, we inquired among the children and the result was this:
John Kicki was the chief of the band. He gave for
reason and they had received no punishment to cause them dis-
content. Moreover, the time of their departure (three days
only before the breaking of the ice) made the members of the
Staff easily believe the boys had not gone any distance, and
consequently, to search within a radius of a few miles, the
first and second day.

I frankly confess that I cannot understand how
any accusation of negligence could be substantiated against
the Father Principal of the School.

I thank you very sincerely for the interest you
take in the welfare of the Indians, concerning their education;
Thank you also for the advice you have given in your letter
concerning situations and occurrences like those of last April.

Yours very truly in Christ,

You state "that it is felt that a more determined effort should have been made by the Principal and Staff to locate these boys."

The Principal himself was confined to the hospital for a severe illness at the time of the evasion. Nevertheless, it being during the night of the 18th-19th April that the boys escaped, the search for them began on the 19th. This is absolutely false, however; the principal of the Albany Residential School has thorough experience of life conditions in James Bay District and is conscientious in the discharge of his duty as a Missionary and Educator. He has devoted twelve years of his life to the welfare of the Indians and has not spared himself in his task.

As soon as the boys had gone, contact was made with the Attawapiskat Mission by wireless, and the Father in charge of the latter notified the father of the leader of the truants. This Indian immediately set off for Albany. The break-up of the ice is later at Attawapiskat than at Albany. As no further news were heard from this man, it was believed that he might have already found the three boys. An accident had happened to him and he had given up the search. It had then become utterly impossible to continue looking for the truants, because of the break-up of the ice on the Albany River; in fact, only three full days elapsed between the departure of the boys and the breaking of the ice. Conditions of broken ice, jammed and moving at times make traveling impossible on or across any river. This and only this was the real cause of the loss of the three boys.

On arriving at Albany and learning with all evidence that hope was no more, Charlie Kicki and his wife, parents of the leader of the truants, showed not the least attitude of reproach toward the Father Principal. Not a word was uttered by them against the Staff of the School, but they burst into tears and with great spirit of faith, loudly spoke to God words of deep resignation. The opposite might have been expected from them at the time. You will please find enclosed a translation of the letter they sent to the Father in charge at Attawapiskat. Translation of the letter written by the same to Albert Matinas.

"Letter of consolation."

"My friends whom I love and with whom I share suffering, I wish to console you although I suffer from anguish myself; but wishing to show you that I love you, being at heart (i.e., feeling as you feel) exactly as you are, I beseech you to accept as I do, this suffering. I wishing to accept it with meekness for the sake of God. For God Himself is the one who will judge us. With patience let us accept our suffering to please Him and to please our children (the three dead boys) who see us and who see God. Let us hope that the bodies may rise again, just as we lost them, and let us be consoled by the fact that the body dies only once in this world (on earth). Let us do as God wants us to do, in order to raise those who are the most heavy and so redeem ourselves and to not lose those our children in the next life. If we try to please God in this suffering which He gives us, the heaviest, which He has chosen for us, let us thank Him feeling how much He loves us; and let us listen one to the other with pity we who suffer this suffering for the first time."

"My friends, that is how I accept this suffering given us by God. I cannot go to see you. Their is only one road, I think, the one which leads to the church; that is the only way that I am able to walk.

From this happening I do not wish that rash judgment arise so that (in turn) we be rashly judged. Always, as much as we..."

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the
Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry,
consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical

Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be
permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked
if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be
attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after
the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it imprac-
ticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him.

Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind
might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for
this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach
the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including
an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the state-
ments of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Statement of John Sutherland -

On the Saturday after the boys had left school Father Langleis told me to start searching for them. I searched all day until dark Saturday west of the school, but found no trace of the missing boys.

Early Sunday morning I started East and discovered some tracks, three sets, going in a north east direction which I followed until late in the evening when a storm obliterated all signs and I had to turn back at midnight.

On Monday I did not go out as it was still storming and all signs would have been obliterated.
Statement of Brother Lapointe.

At the time the boys disappeared from school I was detailed to search for them by Father Langleis, who was ill in bed.

On the Sunday following their disappearance I went at 5 a.m. to the Lakes west of the school and searched all day making a circular tour of about ten miles without seeing any signs. On my return I was told by some Indians that someone had been seen on the mainland south east of this Island, and it was assumed that it was the boys. Breaking ice prevented us from going to this point until Wednesday when we took a canoe through the ice floes only to discover that those who had been seen were some other Indians.
Statement of Joseph Kamalatisit

I was at Lac Ste. Anne at the time in 1941 when the three boys left school. I was sick in bed and only heard about it two days later. John Sutherland was searching for them but other Indians were waiting for some instruction to start searching. The ice at that time was very bad and break-up occurred about three days after the boys had left school. John Sutherland searched well but I think more could have been done. The dog team which the Father sent to search should have carried a canoe and they would have been able to search farther, but ice conditions were very bad.
Statement of Charles Kieki - Father of John Kieki

I am not sure that sufficient search was made for my son and the other boys. I would have circled the area for days until tracks were found (at this point Kieki was told that the area had been circled and tracks found which were followed until obliterated by the storm).

I later came to Albany myself from Attawapiskat and saw the men who in June went searching at Chickney Creek, North of Albany (about ten miles) but I think the search was too late then.

After this happened the other children of the school received a lecture from the priest and I think he said they were not to talk about the affair.

(At this point Father Langleis interrupted to say that he had given the children a lecture but that he had told them they were to tell only the truth about the affair).

I heard some of the other children say that one of the three boys had done something for which he was punished and that they ran away for this reason.
