Statement of Father Langleis, cont'd.

Following break-up it was some time before anything could be done as ice and weather conditions made travel impossible. During this time a report was received from an Indian that a small canoe and arrows had been seen on the South shore of the Chickney River about twenty miles from the school. Five Indians were sent to search as soon as it was possible. They were away for three days but found nothing that would indicate that the boys had been in the vicinity of the Chickney River.

No further search has been made and no reports of any kind have come in about the boys.

In the matter of reporting the incident to the R.C.M. Police and the Department I sent a radiogram not later than a week following the disappearance to Father Charland at Massena who immediately wrote to Bishop Belleau who was at the time in Montreal or Ottawa.
Statement of Father Langleis

The three boys John Kieki, Michel Sutherland, and Michel Matinas, left the school Friday night of April 18th, 1941. Cases of truancy have occurred before in which boys always returned the following day, so it was not until Saturday afternoon that I considered it necessary to search for them.

John Sutherland and the lay brothers searched on foot in all directions from the school, starting out Saturday afternoon - continuing the search Sunday and Monday - returning each night.

No tracks or signs of any kind were found except those followed on Sunday by John Sutherland. These tracks were leading in the direction of the Hudson's Bay Company post about five miles away, and were obliterated by the storm on Sunday night. It is not known if these were the tracks of the boys as they appeared to be more or less aimless. It could have been the tracks of hunters.

It was three days before a team of dogs was sent to search for the missing boys because there were not many dogs around as most of the men were away hunting with them and our team was at Massena and did not return until Monday morning. Our team was given a rest on Monday and sent on Tuesday to search for the boys. They went to the north mouth of the Albany river searching in this direction because an Indian had reported that he thought he might have seen the boys in that vicinity. The Indian reporting this assumed it was the boys he had seen only after reaching the Albany post and learning of their disappearance because on his way into the post he had seen what he thought to be one or two people some distance away from him, but had not stopped as he thought it was only somebody hunting.

The men searching with the team found no signs of any kind of the boys and were forced to return due to the breaking up of the river ice, which broke up completely only two hours after they returned.

Upon arrival at Fort Albany on the above date whilst accompanying the Indian Agent, Dr. T.J. Orford, on the annual treaty trip, it was learned that the three exceptionally noted Indian children had run away from the R.C.Mission school at Lake St. Ann around breakup time in April and that nothing had been learned of them since.

Whilst at the R.C.Mission on this date the principal of the school the Rev. Paul LANGLEIS was interviewed regarding the missing children and the following statement was supplied by Father Langleis:

BEGINS:
Lake St. Ann,
June 14th, 1941.

Report on the death of three boys of our Lake St. Ann school at Albany, James Bay.

Names:
John KIOKI, 14 years old, from Attawapiskat.
Michel SUTHERLAND, 13 years old, from Weemusk.
Michel MATINAS, 11 years old, from Attawapiskat.

Statement on each child:
John KIOKI: he had been accepted last year, only after he had promised to be quiet, obedient and respectful. He had already been three years in school and had not given much satisfaction to the members of the staff. He was hard to control.
Michel SUTHERLAND: he was in his second year at school; we have nothing to complain about him.
Michel MATINAS: he was in his first year at school and we have nothing to complain about him.

The fact: In the night, from Friday 13th of April to Saturday 19th, the boys escaped from the dormitory early in the night and went away and we are without news from them since.

What was done to find them:
In the morning, when we noticed these children had escaped, we thought they had been going into the bush around here; so we waited till the middle of the afternoon, hoping they would be back by the evening; because when some do get away in day time, they come back at least in the evening.
Also, we have built two camps, where the children go for picnics in the winter time. So we sent an Indian to visit those camps and walk in the bush around here; the brothers also walked in different directions, but they did not find them.

Nearly all the Indians were away for hunting. On Sunday, they were reported to have been seen at a small distance from here, so the Indians went but found

said that they had not. He was also asked why the matter
had not been reported to the police and why more prompt
action had not been taken to look for them. He stated that
it often happens that a boy will run away for a day but
will return at night at meal time or when it gets dark. They
had expected that the boys would return in this instance.
It is also unfortunate that the boys choose to run away
just before break up time when travelling on the ice is so
uncertain; however, it was learned that Indiana were travelling
for a week after they left school. Father Langlois said
that he had reported the matter to the Mission at Moosonee
but evidently it did not occur to them to notify the police.

2-1-6-41.

4. Whilst at Attawapiskat on the above date the
Fathers of John KIOKI and Michel MATINAS complained to the

(Continued on Page 3.)

COMPLAINED TO THE Indian Agent and the writer regarding the boys being lost, stating that they believed that the boys had been mistreated and that they had not been notified until it was too late for them to go and look for them. The Father of John KIOKI had started out to look for them when he had been notified but shot his finger off accidently in the tent the first night out. They also said that they had heard from the Indians that the boys had not fed well and that their letters were censored and if anything undesirable at the Mission was included in a letter it was torn up by those in charge. Albert MATINAS, father of Michel, said that he had learned from the children that they were told by the priests at the Mission not to speak of anything that they had seen whilst attending school during the winter. Albert MATINAS had another child die at the school.

5. An endeavour was made by the Indian Agent and the writer to explain to these Indians that it was often necessary to discipline children at school and that it was difficult to believe a child regarding treatment received in school as they naturally find it hard to get accustomed to school life and necessary regulations there. This endeavour was not very well accepted and both Fathers said that they would not send anymore of their children to school.

6. There is no doubt that the children have perished, either by starvation or by drowning. The Chiefs of the Indian bands at Albany, Attawapiskat, and Moose Factory have been asked to have all the Indians on the lookout for the bodies whilst travelling along the coast and in the bush.

7. The whole affair is very regrettable and the parents indignation regarding the loss of their children is readily understandable; however, there does not seem to be anything further that can be done at this late date. In view of this the file is being considered closed.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Ottawa, June 4, 1906.

Rev. Sir,

The last inspection report on the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School does not leave a very favourable impression of this institution. There has been an entire change of staff since the last inspection.

The discipline is lax, the Principal being indulgent and disinclined to excite the hostility of parents, and, owing to him being overworked, cannot give effective supervision to the school.

At the time of the inspection the children were not too warmly clad, although there were ample supplies of unused clothing on hand furnished by the Woman's Foreign Missionary Society. The bedding was insufficient and not clean.

The Inspector claims that the location of the school was badly chosen, it being difficult to reach at any season of the year. The site is low and impossible to drain, owing to the water in Lake of the Woods being raised by the heightening of the dam. Raising operations are conducted on small islands, to reach which horses and oxen have to be taken over in the launch. No sound

Mr Pedley:

Yours of the 4th inst., received, reporting on the unsatisfactory condition of the "Cecilia Jeffery Boarding School." This comes as surprise and disappointment. The building when erected was regarded as satisfactory and the drainage was also satisfactory at that time. We just learned from Professor Hart that the waters of the Lake have been raised, which I presume explains the fact that the level of the Lake has been raised. This you state in your letter as a fact, which of course I did not have been anticipated when the building was erected. The site chosen after careful consideration and whilst it was regarded as away from Kenora, on the other hand it was in the neighborhood of the ones to be served. This not only secured children more readily but made it possible to be in constant contact with the parent to their advantage; these were the reasons that prevailed in choosing a site so.

I am putting your letter into the hands of Prof. Hart, the leader, of the Synodical Committee, in charge of the work, and they will give immediate attention and report.

Mr. and Mrs. Dodds who are in charge of that Mission had experience of several years in Indian work and were deemed successful.

I regret the unfavorable report now received. The difficulty of securing satisfactory agents for this work increases, we shall ever try and do the best possible. I am,

Yours faithfully,

Your Committee do not regard themselves as called upon to justify the conduct of the Inspector chosen for the school, but they are surprised at the complaints coming from him. They believe that the Inspector's opinion that it would be impossible to drain the basement of the school is erroneous, and are convinced that this will be evident when the drain is opened and cleaned out. (5) Your Committee regretted to learn that it was very difficult to heat parts of the building and especially the school room. They are of the opinion that the difficulty arises in part at least from the position of the hot air register in relation to a ventilator in the ceiling. Whether the difficulty be due to any extent to the size or the purpose, or to its construction, or the way in which the pipes are placed or their size, they express no opinion. That the Inspector thinks should be found out by those who heat your Committee do not know, but they do desire to call your attention to the greater danger of the want of ventilation in such a building than of cold. Your Committee are also in doubt as to what the Inspector's words "badly in need of repairs", may refer, as although they examined all parts of the building and are convinced that some repairs be made, they saw nothing to warrant such a strong expression.

Your Committee beg to report that the Inspector's complaint that there was no systematic way of supplying the school with water was true at the time of his visit and that the system is not yet what it ought to be, that the explanation of this is that the pump which had been in use for some time had worn out, that another had been gotten and put in its place, that because of the stiffness of the working of this new pump some of the castings of the wind mill broke, and that although new ones have not yet been procured, and consequently wind power cannot be used, water is pumped by hand into the school. Your Committee hopes that in the very near future the wind mill will be repaired and that water for all school purposes will be pumped by it.

Your Committee readily admit that the duties of the Principal of the school are so varied and require his residence at one and the same time at the school and in the station, and therefore getting supplies for the school or doing mission work along the shores of the lake as to render it impossible for him to discharge them all satisfactorily, that they have considered the recommendation of the Inspector of Indian Affairs that two men be appointed to the work, one to be Principal of the school and the other to take charge of the boat and to do the mission work, and are convinced that it would be a mistake to appoint two men entirely independent of each other to this work, (1) because in their judgment the number of Indians to be benefited do not warrant the additional cost; (2) because of the danger of friction arising between two men so situated and (3) because all who have had any experience in recruiting pupils for Indian Schools say that the Principal alone can do this work satisfactorily, as no other can give the personal pledges the Indians require regarding the care of their children. Hence they recommend that a male teacher be appointed who shall also be Assistant Principal and take full charge of the school in the Principal's absence.

In conclusion your Committee would call your attention to the fact that the cost of maintaining this school will be greater in proportion to the number of pupils than that of any other of our other schools for the following reasons: (1) A steamboat is a necessity because of the situation of the school. This has increased the cost from the first. The difference is now further increased by the enforcement of the regulation of the Department of Marine and Fisheries requiring the employment of two men, one having a master's certificate and the other an engineer's. Happily the Principal of the school has passed the examination and received a master's certificate, but instead of engaging an Engineer to be fireman we are now compelled to engage an Engineer at a much higher salary. (2) The cost of keeping horses and cattle is much greater on the lake than on the prairie. The Principal estimated that it will cost $60-00 to raise a steer to the third year and fit him for market, whereas the same quality of animal can be bought on the prairie for $20-00. Hence while other schools save money by raising their own meat the Castle Junction School would lose heavily. But milk must be had and the cost of securing it is even greater in proportion. During the Summer when the feed should cost little or nothing and the supply of milk be most abundant because of the flies the cows all but cease to give milk. For this reason the Principal recommends that only one or at most two cows be kept and that they be stall fed Summer and Winter.

Your Committee beg to report further that since the beginning of mission work in this region soil for raising potatoes for the use of the school has been found not on the land secured by the Foreign Mission Committee for the school, but on two islands some distance from it. In the present state of the land owned by the church it is impossible to do more than estimate very roughly that amount that may be cultivated. A large proportion of the higher land is rock; the lower although good soil is wet. The drainage of this can be drained without much difficulty, but then you have to lay the drainage of what would involve such heavy work.
Your Committee examined the wing which was built last year and found that there is on the ground floor a kitchen, pantry, and storeroom for provisions; that upstairs there are four bedrooms intended for the comfort of the staff; and that the building is in every way satisfactory except that the only provision for heating the bedrooms is that the pipe from the kitchen stove is to pass through the upstairs hall; and that it is proposed to put a drum in the pipe there. Believing this to be altogether inadequate your Committee considered the various ways in which these rooms may be heated and concluded that as there is not sufficient room for a heating stove in the narrow hall, and that in the opinion of the Committee the rooms are too far from either of the furnaces in the older part of the building to have heat conveyed thence, even if these furnaces have sufficient capacity to heat the additional space, recommend that a new furnace be purchased and put in the basement of the new wing.

The Matron called the attention of your Committee to the fact that the storeroom for clothing is in the attic and therefore difficult to reach and that owing to the heat and darkness no notice whatever about it goes out to the children and destroys the clothing. Your Committee recommend that if space can be found a room in one of the other floors be fitted up for this purpose also that lockers for the boys' clothes be fitted up in their dormitory.

The Matron stated that mattresses for the boys' beds are worn out and asked that if the sooner the new single beds be procured. The Committee agreed to recommend that this be done.

The Principal directed the attention of your Committee to the fact that the wind box for pumping water to the school is broken and that all pumping has to be done by hand. The Committee agreed to request the Principal to find the cost of the necessary repairs and unless those should be high, to have the mill repaired at once.

Your Committee inquired into the complaints regarding the school and the manner in which it is conducted made by the Inspector of Indian Agencies to the Department of the Interior.

The first statement in the complaint as sent by the Secretary of the Indian Department is as follows: "The last report of the Inspector of the Carlisle Boarding School leaves an unfavorable impression of this Institution."

The specific matters complained of are: (1) There has been an entire change of staff since the last inspection. (2) The discipline is lax, the Principal being instructed and disallowed to excite the hostility of parents, and owing to his being overworked, cannot give effect to supervision to the school. (3) At the time of inspection the children were not too warmly clad although there were ample supplies of unused clothing on hand furnished by the Women's Foreign Missionary Society. The bedding was insufficient and not clean. (4) The location of the school was badly chosen, it being difficult to reach at any season of the year. The site is low and impossible to drain, owing to the presence of the lake of the Woods being valued by the heightening of the dam. Forming operations are conducted on small islands to reach which the men have to be taken over in the launch. (5) The Inspector found the building cold and no proper precautions taken to retain the heat, and although this is comparatively a new school, it is badly in need of repairs for lack of attention. They have no systematic water supply. The daily needs are dependent on what is brought in pails and barrels.

The first statement is general and stands or falls with the particulars afterwards given.

These are: (1) The change in the staff. This arose mostly out of an attempt to improve the school by the appointment of a new principal, an appointment which your Committee still believe will be justified by the result. (2) Discipline. Your Committee's visit was made during the holiday season so that they had no opportunity of judging of the school's discipline from the conduct of the pupils, but they did ask each member of the staff regarding this and received from each the assurance that there was no laxity in the Principal's discipline. They also learned that the Indians look upon his discipline as being too strict and that a petition for its abatement on the ground and the appointment of another had been prepared and signed by some of the Indians. The Committee are confident that if any error as to discipline were made during the first year the Principal was in charge, they will be corrected very soon by experience. (3) The children were insufficiently clad. Your Committee are at a loss to know what more to make this complaint. The Matron had children of her own and should therefore know something about what children require in the way of clothing. The Committee received ample testimony to the kindness of her disposition and of the attention of the Indian children for her. It is readily admitted that a good number of mattresses were worn out—a dozen your Committee desire to have replaced. Your Committee regret to report that the Inspector's complaint as to the lack of attention to the pail system was justified by...
Indian Mission Committee of the Synods of Manitoba and Saskatchewan.

Report of the Sub-Committee appointed to visit the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

Your Committee left Winnipeg at 7:45 on the morning of July 21st and arrived at the school a little after 9 P.M. On the 22nd they examined all the buildings and their equipment, traversed a large part of the land held by the Church in the interests of the school, examined all departments of the work as far as this was possible during the holiday season when the school is closed, and the scholars scattered over the woods gathering berries for sale, and inquired into the complaints made by the Inspector of the Indian Agencies to the Department of the Interior, and beg to report:

As to buildings:- The residence of the Principal. This is a good building commodious and comfortable. Your Committee found that the cost of painting, which was done last fall by the son of the Principal at a low rate, was very considerably increased by the fact that the building had stood so long unpainted before it was purchased by the Indian Mission Committee and moved on to the school site, thus necessitating the use of a much larger quantity of paint than would otherwise have been required; that the inside had been painted by members of the Principal's family without any other charge than the cost of the paint.

Your Committee found that an excellent cistern had been placed in the second story of the building, that there is a bath room on the ground floor in which a wash basin is placed, but that there is no bath tub, that there is a sink in the pantry and that metallic pipes have been provided to carry the water from the lake to the house, and that water is now pumped through these in a barrel, in the kitchen, but that the pipes are all above ground and are therefore useless in the winter; that there is no means of pumping the water directly from the lake to the cistern, or of taking the water from the cistern to the kitchen and bath room, and that the drain to convey water from the kitchen sink and the bath room to the lake has not been completed and is consequently useless. Your Committee requested the Principal to stick the water pipe to a sufficient depth below the ground to protect them from frost; to make an estimate of the cost of completing the plumbing so as to take the water from the cistern and from the cistern to the kitchen and bath room and of putting a bath tub in the bath room; and also to inquire into the cost of completing the drain from the sink and bath room to the lake and the protection against frost that would be required at the outlet of this drain.

The Stable:- Your Committee noticed that the stable stands on the road between the residence of the Principal and the school; and that not only needlessly marred the beauty of the walk between the two buildings, but also that the treading of the cattle must in times of rain stir up mud not only on this path but also all around the back door of the school, which the animals must pass in going between the pasture and the stable. On consulting with the Principal it was learned that a workshop and also a storeroom are required and that the present stable can be fitted up for this purpose without much cost. Your Committee recommend that a new stable be built to the west of the school, (i.e., between the school and the pasture) and that the present stable be converted into a workshop and storeroom.

School - Outside the School Rooms:- Your Committee found that there is no provision for saving labour in the cleaning out of these; and that the Inspector of the Department of the Interior had recommended that the liquids be drained off and that a box be put in as a receptacle for the solids in such a way that it may be drawn out and emptied from time to time. Your Committee approve of this recommendation.

Your Committee examined the drainage from the school to the lake and learned that for a time it had been impossible to drain the bath tubs and that it had been feared that the lake was backing up into the tubs, but that this fear had been almost entirely removed by the fact that by pressing a rod down the pipe the tubs had been drained so that they are not perfectly dry. Your Committee, although they had no means of determining the levels, are convinced that unless the lake rises very considerably higher than it was during their visit, there is plenty of rail to drain the basement of the school; and consequently advised the Principal to open the drain so as to determine whether the lack of drainage arises from a stoppage in the drain. Your Committee found that the floor in the boys' bath room had been laid on the clay and that parts of it are so badly broken that the clay is exposed in places, and that consequently it is impossible to keep the floor clean and neat. Your Committee recommend that a cement floor be put down. Your Committee further recommend that in a part of the basement in which there is at present an earthen floor either a stone or a cement floor, etc., determined after further inquiry be laid.

Heating of the school rooms:- The attention of your Committee was directed to the fact that there is but one hot air register in the room and that the heat is not distributed evenly throughout the room.

In support of the application to have the channel improved at Ash Rapids, attention is directed to the following considerations:

Navigation is impossible under present conditions. There is only two feet five inches of water in the shallowest part of the passage at present which makes it impassable for everything but gasoline boats of trifling size. Even when the water is higher, the rapids are difficult and hazardous.

When the writer visited the place a few days ago he counted nine propeller flingers in the water or on the bank which had evidently been broken off by steamers that had struck the rocks. And along the shore are thrown the remains of wires cables and brackets which had been broken in the attempt to warp steamers over the obstructions.

The undertaking is the public interest. Coal lake is a considerable body of water about fourteen miles long, one mile wide and about nineteen feet deep. Its only means of communication with the outer world is through Ash Rapids and the lake of the woods. The industries now in operation on Coal lake include two gold mines in operation, the W. H. Kodo and the L. A. M. Mine (or Cameron Island Mine) and half a dozen others which have buildings erected but are awaiting more favorable conditions, an Indian boarding school, under the care of the Presbyterian Church, which has now an attendance...
enlarged to accommodate ninety... a fishery which
would be two steamers and scattered farmers along the
shores of the lake. During the recent visit of the Dominion
Government engineer who made a survey of the rapids,
in the course of twenty-four hours, three steamers and
three gasoline motor boats arrived at the rapids, (not
including the boat in which the Government party was
voted). The steamers had to transfer their goods but the
gasoline boats, with a good deal of bumping on the rocks,
managed to get through.

The improvement is asked for not only by those whose
business interests are immediately involved, but also by
the Nevers Board of Trade, the Foreign Mission Committee
of the Presbyterian Church, and every public man
part of the country who knows the circumstances.

The cost is likely to be small because the amount of rock
rock to be blasted is not great. The chief work is the removal
of boulders, the expense of which is inconceivable.

Sir,

Your letter giving instructions to report on the channel between the Lake of the Woods and Shoal Lake, was mislaid by Mr. Davies, Assistant Engineer, hence I am unable to refer to the file number. I trust that it will be found and sent to you later.

An examination was made July 17th, and showed that the obstructions are in what are known as the Ash Rapids, connecting the Lake of the Woods with Shoal Lake, through which all boats taking in supplies to the Indian School (supported by the Presbyterian Church) must pass. The rapids are short and contracted, being only 30 feet wide from bank to bank. They are known as the Upper and Lower Rapids, separated by Lock Lake, a body of water about 1800 feet long. The difference in elevation of the Lake of the Woods and Lock Lake is 0.30 of a foot; and between Lock Lake and Shoal Lake 0.90 of a foot. These heights are very much augmented by the wind, which causes the water to rise in either lake, depending upon the way the wind blows.

To obtain a channel five feet deep, and 30 feet wide, it would be necessary to blast and dredge about 467 cubic yards boulders and solid rock. In the lower channel about 232 cubic yards of rock and boulders would require to be removed. As there is no plant which would be available for this work it would be expensive and would cost in the vicinity of $3500.00. The motor boat which the Mission uses draws 4½ feet of water, so that a five foot channel would be necessary at the present time, when the water is extremely low in the lakes.

The necessity for improving these rapids is problematical. At present the Indian Mission or school are the principal ones using it.
Referring to your letter of August 8th, calling attention to the difficulty experienced in navigating Ash Rapids near Shoal Lake, an extension of the Lake of the Woods, I enclose copy of a report from our District Engineer at Winnipeg in which he estimates the cost of excavating a channel at £3500.

Dear Mr. McPhie:

I wish to bring to your notice and in the attention of the Department an act of courage on the part of one of our boys which is seldom paralleled and which I think deserves some sort of recognition, for at the risk of his own life he saved a man who accompanied him from drowning.

Our mail had been brought out to the survey camp at the head of Indian Bay. Yesterday, Dec. 11th, I wrote Mr. McPhie to go over and bring the mail from the camp. Mr. O'Brien, chemist in charge of the laboratory in connection with the Winnipeg water supply, said he would go with him as he had some business to attend to there. They were skating and when crossing Snowshoe Bay they came upon thin ice and both broke through and went down in the water at the same time, after breaking the ice at the edge in several attempts to get out but at last succeeded in getting on the ice where he lay for a short time chilled and exhausted to get his breath. Then,
seeing Mr. Aitken with a heavy coat on struggling in the water and unable to get out, he went over to where he was and, believing that if he broke in again they would both drown, he went near enough the edge to seize Mr. Aitken's hand and, exhausted as he was himself, managed to pull him out of the water. Mr. Aitken himself assured me that he could not have got out if Alex had not come to his assistance, as he was becoming numb and helpless in the icy-cold water.

I might add that an Indian passing a short distance from the place saw them struggling in the water and refused to go to their assistance because he feared that he might break in himself if he went near the spot.

I think that this case might very reasonably be brought to the attention of the Secretary for the Carnegie Hero Fund.

Sincerely yours,

Information required by Carnegie Hero Fund Commission

The rescue took place on December 11, 1913, at 9 o'clock A.M. in Snowshoe Bay, at the west end of Thoral Lake, an arm of the Lake of the Woods, near the western boundary of the Province of Ontario.

The name of the rescuer is Alec Mandamin. He is in his 17th year, weighs 132 lbs., is 5' ft. 7 inches in height, and is at present, as he was at the time of the accident, a pupil of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School. His winter address is Sagoyet, Ont., summer-home, Ont.

The name of the man rescued is Charles E. Athien. His address is Sagoyet, Ont., age 23, height 6 ft. and ½ inch, weight 160 lbs. He is an analytical chemist in the employ of the Greater Winnipeg Water Commission.

Snowshoe Bay, at the west end of Thoral Lake, where they were skating when the ice broke, precipitating them into the water, is about a mile in width and where the accident happened was in the middle of the bay. The water is 20 feet deep, in some supply wells, to which the rescuer went after a change of clothing could be obtained, is a mile and a half from the scene.

The two above mentioned were skating - located near each other about four or five yards, when they came upon thin ice which broke under their weight, precipitating them into the water simultaneously. The boy, Alec, wore his ordinary winter clothing without overcoat as he thought he would be warm enough skating without it; after being in the water about five minutes, during which time he
made several attempts to get out, the ice breaking again and again so his weight came on it, he succeeded in getting on the ice where he lay a few moments to recover breath. Then seeing Mr. Aitken still struggling in the water he went over to him and venturing near enough the edge of the broken ice to grasp his hand succeeded in pulling him out of the water on the ice. Naturally the boy might be expected to be unversed and somewhat exhausted by his plunge into the icy water and his subsequent efforts to get out the success of which seemed for a time doubtful.

The risk and danger consisted in this—that the ice which had broken repeatedly under his weight while endeavouring to extricate himself might break again if he went sufficiently near the edge to grasp the man struggling in the water, but if he succeeded in getting hold of him the chances were twenty to one that the weight of the man in the water added to his own would cause the ice to break and both would be in the water again. He faced that danger and took the risk believing if that happened in the condition he was in then they would have both drowned. They can both swim fairly well but are not expert swimmers. They were in a precarious condition when they reached the school, chilled to bone, with their clothes frozen stiffly stiff. The boy was given dry clothes, hot drinks &c., and kept inside until thoroughly warm, he seemed none the worse afterwards.

There were no other eyewitnesses.

Mr. Aitken informed me afterwards that he could not have got out without assistance. He said that when the boy climbed the ice to pull him out his face was
felt out there was a firm determined expression upon it which said distinctly though inaudibly—"I will see you or die in the attempt."

We all think that he showed extraordinary coolness, courage and determination.

Yours Truly,

H. T. Dodds
Principal
Cecilia Jeffery Boarding School
Engelbostel

Your letter of February 16, giving information on the case of Aloc, Mandamin, only received.

The Carnegie Hero Fund applies to acts in which conclusive evidence may be obtained showing that the person performing the act voluntarily risked his own life saving, or attempting to save, the life of a fellow-being.

I beg to state that we have found it necessary to adopt a rule not to consider cases in which there were no eye-witnesses to the essential details of the act. Therefore, I regret to say, we cannot proceed further with this case. You will understand, I am sure, that the application of the rule in this instance is not in any way intended as a reflection upon the veracity of the rescuer or rescued.

In December the Rev. P. T. Dodge, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School, reported through Agent McKenzie that Alec Mandamin, No. 29 of the school, risked his life in endeavouring to save from drowning Mr. Charles E. Aitken. The matter was brought to the attention of The Carnegie Hero Fund with the request that Mandamin receive recognition for his bravery. The evidence, while conclusive, consists of a circumstantial account of the accident by Mandamin and by Mr. Aitken, the man who was rescued. There were seemingly no eye witnesses. The result is that The Carnegie Hero Commission states that it will not be possible for them to proceed further with the case as they have adopted a rule not to consider cases in which there were no eye witnesses of the essential details of the act.

Mandamin's act of bravery was also reported by the Department to The Royal Canadian Humane Association, and is still under consideration by that society.

When Agent McKenzie first presented this case to the Department, (December 17th last), he remarked that he considered the boy should receive some recognition for his bravery. It is possible that he may yet be given a medal by
by The Royal Canadian Humane Association, but I beg to point out that in the case of bravery exhibited by Indians in British Columbia the Department recognized the noble conduct of the individuals by granting assistance to them, and it occurs to me that we might do something out of the ordinary for Mandamin. If you approve of the suggestion his case might be noted as deserving of special consideration when he makes a start in life.

Winnipeg, Man., August 16th

Sir,

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo in regard to the report circulated on the Lake of the Woods to the effect that one of the pupils of the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School had been severely punished by the Principal and shortly after had sickened and died. It was thought partly from the effects of the punishment.

In reply to your question as to whether an investigation was made into the circumstances of the case I beg to say that the matter became the subject of immediate enquiry by me.

The result of my finding was that the report was untrue as intimated in my Report of the Kenora Agency dated July 8th, 1914.

The facts are as follows:

The girl in question was classed as good and never at any time did she merit punishment. She died from a complication of troubles resulting from measles. Her death was regretted by all.

The Principal gave me his solemn avowal that he never punished in his life and Mrs. Dods confirmed the statement. She was acting Matron at the time of the girl's demise.

I made enquiries as to the origin of the report and found that a Conjurer a member of the Snow Lake Band No. 40 had circulated the report. His attitude toward the School has been one of continued opposition. He is an old-time pagan and dislikes the religious element adopted in the management of the Institution and has done everything in his power to prevent parents from sending their children to the School.

When this was ascertained I made it my business to correct the report at every point and Mr. Dods was present to confirm the statements of the Agent and myself by his own testimony.

The fact remains that the Principal has resorted to corporal punishment at times and the children have reported this to
their parents and dissatisfaction is the result and recruiting has been made difficult in this way.

The Principal has been advised by me to adopt other means of correcting the pupils so as restore confidence and I hope that my next visit will find a happier state of things.

I have the honor to be

Your Obedient Servant

Inspector of Indian Agencies & Schools

He volunteered the barges in about two or three weeks. I asked him if he could take them back with him as he was going to return to another load. He promised me he would turn up by then in the morning and take them to return for another load. As he was going anyway, I never showed up until Nov. 7th. Came up and took the barges to the basement. They remained there until this summer.

I was frozen in at Indina Bay with my men until Nov. 14th. When I got back Red Sky took his Indians to Pointe au Chene to build a station in the CPR about 18 miles.

On account of failure to carry out his contract with me, I was obliged to elect a load from myself to Indina Bay and haul the lumber in with teams. If he had done what he agreed, I could have completed the buildings in 20 days. Saved my time and expenses consequently we had to work all winter. In addition, I missed this spring.

I may state that the Rat Palace lumber Co. took the big barge through with 10 tons a house load, whereas I would have had two days' labor.

Dear Sir:

Yours of the 14th inst. To hand in reference to the number of pupils in Cecilia Jeffrey school for which the per capita grant is paid. I understand when the building was constructed and enlarged in accordance with the plans of the government architect that the agreement providing for 40 pupils only was cancelled and that payment would be made for a larger number of pupils according to the capacity of the building and the accommodation afforded. The reason, as I understand it, for limiting the number of pupils in any school is to prevent overcrowding. I had asked to have the building enlarged sufficiently to accommodate 70 or 75 pupils, and when space was provided for a larger number I can see no reason why we should be tied down to an old agreement which should have been automatically cancelled.

After the expense of enlarging and improving the school, visiting the Indians in order to
assure them of the additional comfort and accommodation, and when they are willing to send their children to the number of 60 or 70, it is not very encouraging to be informed that the per capita grant is provided for only forty pupils.

This makes the grant for much quarter alone about $200 less than we had expected, and at a time, too, when the advance in the price of almost everything makes the keeping up of the school and the carrying on of the work a very difficult problem even with the grant paid for all the children attending.

I therefore suggest that the department be informed through its Agent or Inspector, or both, of the maximum number of pupils our school can accommodate, and that the per capita grant be paid for all pupils admitted attending, up to that number, from the first of January, 1915.

Yours Truly,

Memoranda Re Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School

(1) For some years the Cecilia Jeffrey School has been poorly managed as my reports have shown from time to time.

(2) There have been extenuating circumstances which have also been mentioned in my reports and while I have criticised as in duty bound I have never been without hope of better things when the conditions should improve.

(3) Lately the Department has increased the capacity of the School and improved the heating etc so that the Staff has had a better chance to show good results.

(4) The attendance has much increased within the last year and with the consequent additional income the Principal has made much advancement in efficient management so that our last report shows a very good state of things—indeed a complete transformation has taken place which we have had great pleasure in reporting.

(5) The present attendance of Pupils is 54. The average attendance for last quarter was 46-65. More pupils are applying so that the attendance for the coming season is estimated at 65.

(6) Lately the Department through Agent Mc Kenzie has notified the Principal the Rev F.T. Dodds that the grant can only be paid for 40 pupils as per agreement on record. This means a loss of £200.00 on the March Quarter and this amount of loss will be greater in the June quarter when it is expected more pupils will be in attendance.

(7) There are sixty children's cots in the Dormitories and my report of February 1914 states that there is accommodation for 60 to 65 pupils. It seems to me to be advisable to have the Department authorize the admission of a greater number than forty so that the present level of efficiency may be maintained, and the number now on the roll be kept in the School. Where so many applicants are found willing to attend it is a pity to turn them down, especially as there are hundreds of children on the Inspectorate not attending any School.

Respectfully Yours

Dear Mr Scott,-

On the morning of the 8th inst I received the following telegram:

Rev John Semmens
Kenora Ont Sept 7th 1915

An important question has arisen regarding two of our pupils. Consulted Agent about it and he thought you ought to come to Kenora or to the school at once to investigate and decide what should be done. Will you wire me at Kenora if you can come and when.

P.T. Dodds

To this I replied:

Rev P. T. Dodds
Care Indian Agent
Kenora- Ont

Will leave for Kenora Thursday morning. Better meet me there.

John Semmens

I left Winnipeg on the first train September 9th and arrived at Kenora at 11:20 A.M.

Mr Dodds and Agent Mc Kenzie met me at the Depot and we made arrangements to meet immediately after dinner.

Met Mr Dodds as arranged at 1:30 P.M. in Agent's Office Kenora and asked the Principal to state his case. He said:

Two of the girl pupils of the school have broken the laws of the School in a very serious way. They were taken out by Miss Mc Cormie with other girls for exercise and after going some distance into the woods Beatrice Mah-lah-Pen-Ais aged 15 and Betty Mah-jah-ke-sik of the same age decided to return to the school and were allowed to do so. Instead of returning to the School they went into the woods with some boys and returned some considerable time after. This had occurred on Sunday the 5th of September.
claimed that these girls had been stubborn and wilful in various ways and would not try to learn English and now that this had happened he felt that they should either be sent to Elkhorn or be expelled and sent back to their Reserve.

I asked the Principal if he had held any investigation at the time the offence happened and he admitted that he had only heard from the assistant Matron that this had been reported to her by a pupil.

At this point attention was called to the fact that Miss Cormie had been remiss in permitting these girls to return to the School alone and that the Principal should have informed himself thoroughly by a personal enquiry from all parties concerned.

Learning that the two girls had been brought in with a view to their immediate expulsion and return to their homes I sent for them and questioned them closely. They admitted that they had been in the company of two boys and that they had walked with the boys knowing this to be a violation of school regulations. They denied having had any improper relations with the boys and there was no evidence to prove that this was the case.

It was found further that they were orphans and had no very near friends to take care of them at Lac De Lille Laos and it was considered that further misfortune might possibly await them there and that danger of want and starvation might result so after reasoning the circumstances out I came to the following conclusions:

(1) It was their first serious offence and reasonable leniency should be shown.

(2) There was no proof of actual immorality and they should have the benefit of the doubt.

(3) They are under age and might go wrong or starve if sent home and continued guardianship would be beneficial.

(4) Sending them to another school might if undesirable consequences should follow involve the reputation of that School.

With these thoughts in my mind I administered a severe reproof to the girls, and warned them of consequences, and made them promise never again to break laws made for their protection, and demanded a
I solemnly promise from each girl that they would observe school regulations for the future if taken back. When this promise had been given in the presence of the gentlemen present in the room, the girls standing on their feet and making affirmation as required, I turned to Mr. Dodds and asked him if after this he would give his consent to try the honesty of their resolution for a longer period. He consented to take them home and see if better conduct would manifest itself.

At the same time I felt that it would be necessary to exercise a special watch over these girls and if it should be found that they were to become mothers the fact should be reported to the Department with a request for their expulsion. This was impressed upon the Principal as he seemed to think that the Agent could take such action without reference to the Superintendent General or his deputy.

Steamer Wanderer left at once for the Cecilia Jeffrey School and I returned to Winnipeg the same evening.

I have the honor to be

Dear Dr. Grant:

Yours of the 13th inst. to hand, with letter from the Secretary of the Indian Department enclosed. Miss Brodie, our teacher, insists that the figures quoted and the statements made in the letter from the Department, in reference to the handling of pupils, are correct. But she refuses to promote pupils from one standard to another until they are prepared for it by a thorough knowledge of all that is included in the standard they are leaving. She states that usually it requires from two to three years for white children to pass the first and second parts of standard one, whereas they are not handicapped as Indian children are by ignorance of the English language.

In reference to changes in the staff last summer, we had quite a number which seemed unavoidable. Since then there have been none except the addition of one more member. But what has changed in other departments to do with the class-room? Miss Brodie has been in charge of that for two and a half years, except the short time (about two months) that Mr. Bates relieved her. How can the "most unsatisfactory" conditions in the class-room be attributed to frequent changes there. If the criticism is intended to apply to and reflect upon those who preceded Miss Brodie in the class-room then I think it is rather broad.

Miss Brodie assures me that this unsatisfactory state of affairs is no reflection upon her methods or work, and has no reference to her. To prove the latter, she has in her possession a copy of the part of Inspector Semmens' official report which refers to her and the class-room work, sent to her privately by Inspector Semmens, and which is so flattering and eulogistic that she is ashamed to show it to anyone. She, however, stated incidentally that Nurse Stratton had seen it and had pronounced it "every word true".

Now, waiving altogether the injudicioumess, not to say irregularity, of such procedure on the part of an inspector, I heard Mr. Semmens express dissatisfaction with Miss Brodie's method of teaching when he was in the class-room at the time of his inspection, and I leave it with him and Miss Brodie to harmonize the copy of his report with either, which gives her so much satisfaction, and the one sent to Ottawa upon which is based the letter sent to you complaining of "most unsatisfactory" conditions in the class-room. REPORT OF INSPECTOR SEMMES ON THE CECILIA JAFFEY BOARDING SCHOOL.

REPORT DATED - January 22nd, 1917.

STATE OF DISCIPLINE -

I am unable to report perfect deportment out of the school room. Pupils are rather refractory. The Indian language is still used by pupils to an undesirable extent. The Indian parents visit the school frequently and remain for meals and talk a great deal with the children. More than this it is feared that they encourage their children in disobedience and they resent every form of punishment. Complaints of the pupils are too readily believed by their guardians and the Principal finds that their interference makes his work doubly hard.

Much trouble has been occasioned lately by the exchange of notes between girl and boy pupils and clandestine meetings have been arranged and carried out. Several children have run away lately and have been shielded and retained by the fathers. Happily this was corrected by our visit and the children are back again and it is to be hoped that advice given may have the effect of checking the abuses which have occasioned much trouble and misunderstanding. The Principal is very kind and conscientious and forbearing, but he must needs assert his authority and retain his position as Master of the situation. He gives me the assurance that he never punishes severely and that he only uses a strap on the open hands of law breakers.
Ottawa, February 1st, 1917.

I am about to make a report that four boys, two from West Angle came in last summer, one from Aurora, son of the late Edward Land, one John Edward Kipling from the Dollies, and one Chief David Lands from Selkirk. These boys, together with some others, had been implicated in the pilfering of goods and breaking into and stealing from three rooms in the school. I punished only one of them mildly, the other three not at all. That was a week ago or a little over. Since then I talked with them and they promised to do better, but have not. They are insolent, disobedient and defiant. Today, however, they were so reckless and insolent that I determined to have them brought before me in the office today, but they shipped out in the night.

I think that all those boys who have left the school without permission ought to be brought under
control in some way, and either compelled to return to the school or placed somewhere under restraint where they could not run home wherever they pleased. And I think the most effective way would be for the Indian Department to take action in the matter. If these boys are allowed to leave the school when they choose to do so and to remain away and be left free, their actions will infect the whole school. It has done so already to a considerable degree, and this infection will spread. Thugs to run away are quite common already among the younger pupils if they are subjected to discipline or control, or if any restraint is put upon them. So you see this has become a vital question, and if action is not taken soon, the efficiency of the school will, I believe, be greatly impaired and our efforts for the education of our Indians in large measure frustrated.

Rev. Sir,

Since writing you on the 29th of March, last, in reference to the management of the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School I beg to say that a report has been received from our Inspector, which shows that no improvement in the management of this school has taken place since then and I cannot do better than quote from the Inspector's report as follows:

"The history of the school named since last inspection has not been marked by that tranquility, which is most desirable; nor by that harmony of action between officers which one loves to observe.

"Quite a number of the children have run away, and have travelled through all sorts of hardships to reach their distant homes. When such things happen on an extensive scale, one begins to look about for some adequate cause, and careful enquiry showed that two reasons were given, first, too much hard work, and second frequent punishment. Information showed that boys were not treated with the same leniency which marked the treatment of the girls, and that when the Principal enforced discipline he displayed considerable temper, possibly forgetting his own strength, and without realizing that the subjects of correction were only children after all.

"While this information may in the main be correct

Rev. J. H. Edmonson, B.A.,
Secretary,
Board of Home Missions,
Presbyterian Church in Canada,
434 Confederation Life Building,
Toronto, Ont."
It is nevertheless to be received with some reserve. Indian children are not subject to much severity at home and it would perhaps be better for them if they were. Parents and guardians sympathize too deeply with the juniors and, it is believed, that they encourage them to resent all forms of punishment. The Principal is a good man and it is hardly likely that he would resort to corporal punishment such as is said to be given or that he would allow his temper to become ungovernable as reports suggest.

However, the fact remains that the boys are held to be well nigh incorrigible; and on the other hand, the Principal is regarded as hasty and severe in his chastisements. Pupils lack interest in their work and prefer the hardships of a wild run through the forest to remaining under the discipline given.

"The Chiefs of Reserves No. 39 and 40 living within a mile or so of the school complain that days are allowed to elapse from the time of desertion before they were notified of the flight of the boys; and that, in the meantime, such a start was gained that they were unable to trace and bring them back. Had the facts been given to them in due time they might have tracked and overtaken them and restored them to the custody of the management, but delay was unfortunate.

Further than this, bad feeling seems to exist between the Chiefs and the Principal; so much so, that the latter has notified the Indians that he will not allow them to get meals at the institution, or travel on the steamer, or have their freight brought out from Kenora free, as aforetime. It is understood that this action was taken in punishment for the offence of sending a letter of complaint to the secretary of Indian Affairs last winter. In this the Principal may not have been very judicious. Our conclusion was
Was that very unpleasant relations between the school management and the people have been established, which it will take sometime to overcome.

"It is hoped that the arrival of the new Assistant Principal, Mr. Matthews, who takes special charge of the boys, will be able to help matters considerably, if he proves to be equable in temperament, wise in action and moderate in the exercise of authority.

"In speaking to the Indians we counselled patience and fair play so that Mr. Matthews might have a chance to show what was in him; and we urged them not to find fault too quickly, or to encourage pupils to be insubordinate, but to report all wrongs to their Agent or Inspector, rather than to take affairs in their own hands.

"There was not that harmony between the Matron and the subordinate officers which we could have desired to find. This raises the question as to whether it is best to have the Principal and his wife in command in the same institution. Sympathies may be so strong between them that a sort of family compact appears. In this case others may for self protection criticise so freely as to awaken secret dislike which later manifests itself in opposition. So often this kind of thing grows from more to more until some one must go to preserve the peace.

"I have no animosity towards Mr. and Mrs. Dodds and I think that I am a friend of the school, but my interest in the work of the Department compels me to give as correct a view as possible to my superior officers and in my humble opinion things have not been promising of late."

In view of this report the Department is forced to the conclusion that the present Principal will not make a success of this school and it would be to the interests of
of the institution that a change should be made.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and secretary.

REPORT of Commission of Presbytery appointed to investigate conditions at "Cecilia Jeffries Boarding School".

Your Committee beg to report:

Your committee visited the Cecilia Jeffries Boarding School on February 20th to 24th, devoting Thursday 21st and Friday 22nd wholly to investigating conditions there.

We went carefully into the matters complained of in the documents submitted by the Department of Indian Affairs under date of August 4th, 1917, first, with the Principal, Rev. F. T. Dodds, afterwards with a number of Indians, including chiefs Nos. 39 and 40, and finally with each member of the staff separately. Most of the forenoon and the whole of the afternoon of the 22nd was spent in hearing the Indians.

To find that there is constant friction between the Indians and the School, which became serious a year ago when it was manifested by an epidemic of truancy on the part of the pupils, frequent punishment, and later a refusal on the part of Indians to allow pupils to return to the school. The prejudices on the part of the Indians against the school management was aggravated by the action of the Principal in discontinuing the furnishing of meals to the Indians and his refusal to carry them on the steamer to and from Kenora as in the past. This condition of unrest and insubordination has not been removed, and your committee has made a very earnest effort to discover the real root of the whole trouble.
In conducting its investigation your committee proceeded along the line suggested by the document forwarded by the Department of Indian Affairs, and in presenting its report will do so by discussing serially the several paragraphs of that document.

1. "Quite a number of children have run away and have travelled through all sorts of hardships to reach their distant homes. When such things happen on an extensive scale, one begins to look about for some adequate cause, and careful inquiry showed that two reasons were given—first, too much hard work, and second, frequent punishment. Information showed that boys were not treated with the same leniency which marked the treatment of girls, and that when the Principal enforced discipline he displayed considerable temper, possibly forgetting his own strength, and without realizing that the subjects of correction were only children after all."

The following is a summary of the truancy cases and the circumstances attending the same according to the discovery made by your committee.

The case of—

1. Wilfred Redsky: who ran away to his home three quarters of a mile across the bay at the end of December, 1916, because he had been punished by hand strapping for having written a suggestive letter to one of the girls. A few weeks later, on the arrival of the Indian Agent and Inspector, the father brought the boy to the school and lodged a complaint against the Principal of cruelty. Evidence as to the nature of the offence and the character of the punishment was given. The representative of the Department expressed no disapproval of the action of the Principal but instructed the father to leave the boy at the school. The boy remained until the July closing, at which time he was unwilling to go home with his father and
ran into the woods and hid while the other children were being taken away. A week later the father returned and by force took the lad away in his canoe.

On the Agent's visit in August, Redaby was summoned to explain why he would not send his children back. He said "Because he did not want his children killed". On being reminded of his son's unwillingness to go home in July, he admitted in the presence of the Agent and members of the staff that because of severe punishment at home the boy preferred being at the school.

2. Samuel Laird, Emma Lichtning and Joseph Redaby:- who ran away about the end of January 1917. These boys had been punished by hand strapping for a clandestine meeting with some of the girls in a house at some distance from the school. They had left the school after dark, but all were discovered and brought back the same night. Six girls and four boys were involved in this adventure. Some days later the three boys named escaped from the school about 11 P.M., but their absence was not discovered until next morning. Laird went north, it was afterwards learned, over the Ingolf trail with which he was familiar, and on to his home at White Dog Reserve. The other two went south to the North West angle, and later to Buffalo Bay and Assiniboia. The Principal has made inquiries about the boys and learned that they suffered no ill effects from their journey. They have never returned and their names have been struck off the register.

3. Edward Laird, cousin of Samuel, John Kipling and
Roy Henry - ran away early in February.

On a Saturday night these boys had broken into the store room and stolen food. During Sunday the boys, when questioned, admitted their guilt and were instructed to report at the office on Monday for punishment. That night they ran away. They had not been previously punished.

4. Norman - ran away during the last week of February.

He had been punished by hand strapping, in December, for being implicated in a case of theft. He had not been punished at any other time. He had only been at the school for five months, and was 14 years of age, so naturally felt its restraint and discipline irksome.

5a. About the same time - 11 girls escaped from their room during the night. They had shown no spirit of insubordination, had gone to their room apparently happy and contented. By the evening of the second day they were all returned to the school.

Since that time there has been occasional running away on the part of small boys to homes in the neighborhood, but all have been quickly returned.

Recently Morris - age 16, who has been a pupil for seven years, has run away. He is reported as being a clever boy and was a favorite with the teachers. Of late she has had occasion to report him to the Principal. By constant infringing of rules and continual insubordination in the class room and in the other departments he merited and received punishment, the regular hand strapping. No effort has been made to secure his return.
At the re-opening in August there was a general refusal on the part of parents to return their children to the school. At that time the Indian Agent visited the Institution, investigated the situation, and insisted on parents sending the pupils back. Since that time the attendance has been increasing until it is now nearly up to what it was two years ago.
