Your committee, after dealing with the general conditions, took up the statement of the Department and examined the causes assigned therein for the frequency of truancy and the apparent spirit of insubordination.

A. The Charge of Overwork -

The Indians were asked for particulars as to the kind and amount of work assigned.

One Indian alleged that small boys were compelled to cut cord wood in winter. No other had any complaint either general or particular under this head. We found that boys had not cut cord wood for five years. At that time boys were given the opportunity of cutting wood on land near the school on Saturdays if they wished, and were paid for their work at current rates. No boy was compelled to engage in such work.
The only other case under this head was an allegation that Mr. Dodds had compelled a boy who was not well, to make the trip to Ingolf for mail in winter; that the boy had returned used up, and had died within two days.

The Principal stated that it had been his fixed rule to ask for volunteers for this service - in no case had a boy been impressed - that in the face of an approaching storm boys had turned back and had been commended for their caution. Four years ago a boy who had volunteered to go for mail, two days after his return complained of being ill. The doctor was made acquainted with his condition and the treatment being given. He approved the treatment but did not think it necessary for him to make the journey to the school. The case developed into pneumonia and resulted in death two weeks after the beginning of the illness. Mr. Dodds further stated that it had never occurred to him to connect the illness with the journey to Ingolf. The Indians now accept Mr. Dodds' statement of the facts.

The members of staff felt that if there were any grounds of complaint on the score of work, it would be on the part of the girls rather than boys, but that no complaints had been made of overworking girls and further references to hard work provoked smiles both from Indians and staff. It seemed strange to your committee that Indians had to hark back five years for grounds to substantiate present day dissatisfaction, mentioning Indians upon the grounds of dissatisfaction justifying them for withdrawing children from the school, in nearly every case they had to go back several years for specific cases. In one instance a
medicine men went back ten years when his boy and three others had died of meningitis and stated that since then he had refused to allow his children to attend the school. In all only seven deaths have occurred at the school in the past ten years.

B. Frequency of punishment -

It was the consensus of opinion of the staff that punishments were not more frequent or more severe than the cases merited. As to the immediate causes and the punishments administered on such occasions we have already reported in certain places.

C. Partiality of treatment -

That girls were treated more leniently than the boys. The Principal averred that punishments were identical when offenses were the same, and members of the staff emphatically repudiated the suggestion of partiality. The only explanation we could suggest for this charge being made, was the Indian tendency to regard the boy as superior to the girl and more worthy of consideration.

D. Temper - "That the Principal had displayed considerable temper when he had enforced discipline."

Members of staff being questioned on this matter, unanimously stated that the Principal was uniformly deliberate; that they had on no occasion witnessed any display of temper, either in dealing with pupils on the premises or in administering punishment; that when girls were punished the nurse was always present and that in no instance had punishment resulted in abrasion of skin or any permanent injury.
II. Paragraph 2:

"While this information may in the main be correct, it in no way tends to be received with some reserve. Indian children are not subject to much severity at home and it would perhaps be better for them if they were. Parents and guardians sympathise too deeply with the juniors and it is believed that they encourage them to receive all forms of punishment. However the fact remains that the boys are held to be well-nigh incorrigible; and on the other hand the Principal is held to be hasty and severe in his chastisements."

With regard to the first sentence of this paragraph, your committee is of the opinion that the Department has been misinformed, as to the work and punishment, and have found no evidence of any adequate reason for the Indians regarding Mr. Dodds as hasty and severe in his chastisements, beyond native prejudice against any manner of corporal punishment. But we do endorse the statement about the treatment of children in their homes.

III. Paragraph 4:

The chiefs of Reserves Nos. 39 and 40, living within a mile or so of the school complain that days are allowed to elapse from the time of desertion before they were notified of the flight of the boys and that in the meantime such a start was gained that they were unable to trace and bring them back. Had the feet been given them in due time, they might have tracked and overtaken them and restored them to the custody of the management, but delay was unfortunate.

Chiefs take considerable credit to themselves for bringing back truant children and Mr. Dodds gratefully acknowledges their assistance.

In the cases complained of, when they were not requested to assist, and which were made the ground of the statement in Paragraph 1 as to hardships endured by runaway boys, very careful
Investigation was made by your committee.

The Principal stated that on these occasions both chiefs No. 29 and 40 were absent from their homes working on wool contracts 10 or 12 miles away. Upon examination, chief No. 30 without knowing that the Principal had said, admitted that he was absent and beyond reach of Mr. Dodds, and could not have rendered assistance by the time word might have been sent him.

In private examination chief No. 40 stated that he was at home the night the boys ran away, but afterwards upon further examination in the presence of Mr. Dodds and a group of Indians stated that he had come home unexpectedly about six o'clock in the evening, after dark, and had returned to his work next morning, leaving home at seven o'clock (before daylight) and that the Principal could have had no knowledge of his visit home on that occasion.

Had the chiefs been sent for on these occasions, according to their own admission they could not have overtaken the boys and further the boys had suffered no ill consequences from their journeys. The complaint of the chiefs in this connection seems to be wholly unjustified.

LV. Paragraph 4:

"Further than this bad feeling seems to exist between the Chiefs and the Principal; so much so, that the latter has notified the Indians that he will not allow them to eat meals at the Institution, or travel on the steamer, or pay their expenses brought out from Kenora free as aforesaid. It is unfortunate that this action was taken in punishment for the offense of sending a letter of complaint to the Secretary of Indian Affairs regarding the conduct of the Principal may not have been very judicious. Our conclusion was that very unpleasant relations between the people and the school management have been established, which it will take some time to overcome."
The charge that the Principal was actuated by bad feeling in declining to furnish any further meals to the Indians, and that this was done as a punishment for their having written a letter of complaint to the Secretary of Indian Affairs, does not seem to be borne out in the light of a letter from the Department under date of February 1st, 1917, which is as follows:

"Ottawa, February 1st, 1917.

Rev. Sir,

Inspector Benson who visited the Cecilia Jeffries Boarding School on the 23rd ultimo has forwarded his report to the Department.

It is noted that the Inspector states that the department of the pupils, outside the school hours, is unsatisfactory.

The Department considers that it would be to your advantage in the maintenance of discipline if you discouraged too frequent visits of parents to the school and discontinued furnishing meals.

The Inspector states that he is assured that you have not punished the pupils severely, and this action on your part is to be commended, still the Department will in future expect you to take a decided stand and deal firmly with those who transgress the rules, in order that the present abuses in the children's conduct may be corrected.

Your obedient servant,
(Sgd) J. W. McLean
Acting Deputy Secretary."

Acting upon the recommendation contained in this letter, the Principal discontinued the meals.

The second charge, that he refused to carry freight is positively denied by the Principal. Every Indian who appeared before your committee to register complaints, including Chiefs 30 and 40, freely stated that they never knew of any instance of such refusal to carry goods for Indians or that the Principal had ever charged for such service. There seems absolutely no foundation
for this charge and the Indians examined seemed surprised that such an allegation had been made.

The cause assigned for the action of the Principal seems irrelevant. Mr. Dodds states that while he had heard during the winter that a letter of complaint had been written, he had no certain knowledge of its contents until sometime in June, several months after he had been declining to furnish meals on the instructions from the Department.

His refusal to carry Indians on the boat was closely related to the question of meals. Indians going on the boat expected to be given breakfast before they started and to be fed on route. On more than one occasion the boat was so crowded with Indian passengers that all the provisions taken for the round trip were devoured before they reached Kenora, so that food had to be purchased for the return trip. Sometimes when the boat remained overnight at Kenora the boat was so occupied by Indians that the crew had to sleep in town. The practice of the Indians making such free use of the steamer had become an intolerable nuisance and in following instructions to cut out the meals the Principal thought it necessary and wise to place restrictions on the use of the steamer. But while refusing to carry passengers, Mr. Dodds at no time refused to carry their freight for them.

Your committee could not discover the date of the Indian's letter of complaint, but it would seem to have fallen between the receipt of the recommendation of the Department and the opening of navigation. In this whole matter the Principal
seems to have been carrying out to the best of his ability the instructions of the Department in their letter of February 1st.

Apparently the chiefs and Indians were not aware that Mr. Dodds was acting under instructions in this connection, and expressed surprise when informed that such was the case. The Principal has himself borne the brunt of the antagonism occasioned by this change in their treatment without making any effort to shield himself behind the Government. When we so informed the Indians they appeared to be greatly mollified. Chief Reddy gave what seemed to be rather an unwilling assent to their change of view, but promised to go back to his Reserve and tell his people these things and that Mr. Dodds had not acted with any desire to punish them for what they had done.

VII.

Paragraph seven reads:

"There was not that harmony between the Matron and the subordinate officers which we could have desired to find. This raises the question as to whether it is best to have the Principal and his wife in command in the same Institution. Sympathies may be so strong between them that a sort of family compact exists; in this case, others may for self protection criticize so freely as to awaken secret dislikes which later manifests itself in opposition. So often this kind of thing grows from more to more until someone must go to preserve the peace."

In the judgment of your committee it is when we come to deal with conditions set out in this paragraph that we discover circumstances, which combined with the misapprehension of the Indians regarding the meals and other privileges have produced the state of unrest, suspicion and insubordination prevalent in the school.

"We failed, however, to discover any evidence of a 'family compact' because of the Matron being the wife of the..."
Principal. All members of the staff stated emphatically that such a compact did not exist.

We did not discover that there had been any breach between Matron and members of the staff—nor was there any lack of loyalty on their part towards the Matron. There was in fact a sense of duty on the part of the staff that in itself was sufficient to prevent anything like disruption.

It seemed however clearly evident that there was a nervous anxiety on the part of the Matron for the success of the School, and a tendency to worry over the details of all departments that has led her to unnecessary interference with both pupils and members of staff. This lack of tact in general management—understood and overlooked by some—is tacitly resented by others.

While pupils require close and constant guarding and observation, this supervision has not been as wisely directed as could be wished, and pupils themselves have been made to feel that they were under suspicion by the issuing of instructions to members of staff in their presence. The thought that they were under suspicion has developed in them a spirit of rebellion, which breaks out in acts of insubordination. This whole atmosphere was revealed in a few phrases of the Indians when they said: "Things are not right in here" (referring to the internal economy of the school). "There is something to blame." "There are too many watchers." "Children don't like to be watched." "They want to run away."

These conditions within the Institution in conjunction with the resentment felt by parents occasioned by the cutting off
The meals and restriction of beat privileges, have combined to produce the present conditions - conditions by no means unknown on other reserves.

The suggestion that there might be a sort of family compact was not supported by any member of the staff, all affirmed that the Principal had been uniformly impartial. The only justification for such a suggestion, might be the anxiety of the matron to spare her husband unnecessary worry. As to the general principle that it is not advisable to have both husband and wife in authority in the same institution, we do not agree with the Report. The same relation exists at the Portage La Prairie Boarding School - and those acquainted with conditions there, regard that very relation as an important factor in the successful management of that institution.

We regret that the health of Mr. Dodds has been so greatly impaired and that increasing years make it inexpedient for himself to continue very much longer in the work, yet we are strongly of opinion that his removal at this juncture would be construed by the Indians as the direct result of their appeal to the Department and a victory on their part. Such a sense of victory would be disastrous and would certainly lead to trouble for his successor in the future.

We would express the hope that the Department stand by the Principal in the enforcement of discipline for a further period, pending the changes entailed by his retirement. Our judgment has been confirmed in this by the splendid results following the action of the Agent in dealing with the Indians in
August - (action which Mr. Dodds cordially recognizes and appreciates) - when the Agent insisted on the return of the children to the School. Continued support for the coming summer would do much in restoring right relations between the Indians and the Institution.

Upwards of two years ago Mr. Dodds warned the Home Mission Board that the time was drawing near when he must be relieved, and suggested the appointment of an assistant who might become acquainted with the many phases of the work in this particular school. To your committee Mr. Dodds expressed the opinion that Mr. Matthews, the present assistant, would acquire during this year that familiarity with the work that would warrant his appointment to the Principalship.

In view of these facts and in view of the fact that Mr. Dodds has rendered 21 years of efficient service in Indian work and has had his work favorably reported on year after year, we consider that his removal at this juncture would be unjust, as well as detrimental to future discipline.

Therefore, we recommend that Mr. Dodds be continued in charge sufficiently long into the summer to enable Mr. Matthews to become acquainted with the navigation of the lake, after which time Mr. Dodds might be relieved from further responsibility.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

(Signed) Hugh J. Robertson,
Convener of Committee.

S. C. Murray.

Dear Mr. McLean:

I have yours of March 25th, re the situation at Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School.

At the meeting of our Home Mission Board last week, we had presented to us the report of the Commission appointed by Winnipeg Presbytery to look into the situation. I am enclosing copy of the Commission's report. After full discussion, the following resolution was passed:

"The Board, having heard the report of the Commission of Winnipeg Presbytery re the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, received and adopt the same, and instruct the Secretary to forward it to the Department of Indian Affairs; and would strongly urge upon the Government their support of the Principal in the conduct of the work, assured that if he stand by him through the present period of unrest, the spirit of disloyalty or rebellion will disappear; and that failure to do so, they are only inviting future difficulty; for the Department and for the next Principal of the school; and would assure the Government that changes to take place during the year that will substantially improve the situation, without bringing to the mind of Indians the impression that they can control the situation."

I may say that since the meeting of our Board, I have received a communication from Mr. Doddie. He does not approve of the finding, and tender his resignation, this to take effect June 30th. He has been promised Mr. Matthews that he remain in charge during the summer. This Mr. Matthews an opportunity to get his hand on the work. I hope we may be able to maintain his services during the summer.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Rev. J. M. Robinson, B.A.,
Secretary of the Board
Mrs. Dodds has sent in her resignation as Matron. She desires that this resignation shall take effect forthwith. Our Women's Missionary Society is now endeavoring to find someone to take her place. As soon as a successor is secured, Mrs. Dodds will be relieved. We are confident to Mr. Dodds that as soon as a new Matron is secured, he and Mrs. Dodds move over to the Mission residence, and that Mr. and Mrs. Matthews, with the new matron, take charge of the School Home. This would relieve him of the discipline of the School and it would leave him comparatively free for the summer months. It would give him an opportunity of giving to Mr. Matthews the instruction and direction that he may require in the direction of the school and the management of the boat. We, of course, do not know as yet whether Mr. Dodds will consider our proposal, but I hope it will meet with the approval of the Department.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR SEMMENS ON THE CECILIA JEFFREY BOARDING SCHOOL.

The dispensary department was visited and carefully noted as this is regarded as an important branch of school work. The lady in charge is Mrs. Fraser. She is a certificated nurse and was appointed to the position now held by the Department of Indian Affairs. Her monthly allowance comes from the Department through the Presbyterian Church, Toronto. As I have visited from time to time I have come to regard Mrs. Fraser as a superior type of woman, as a capable and conscientious nurse, as a faithful and devoted member of the school staff and as an exemplary christian lady. Her work was well done, the infirmaries were very clean and orderly and she appeared to have a knack of ministering to the sick, and of nursing them back to health which marked her as a person of special worth.

Imagine my surprise when the Principal refused to endorse a voucher looking to the issuance of a cheque for her last month's salary which the agent presented for his signature. On being pressed for a reason, the Principal said that Mrs. Fraser had not been subject to discipline, had violated the rules of the school in several instances and was more or less of a gossip; so that he could not attach his signature to the voucher but would give his permission for the Assistant Principal Mr. Matthews to do so if he would. Mr. Matthews refused to sign believing there was something in what the Principal had stated and that while he might be disposed to act in an emergency in the absence of the Principal, he felt it would not be right for him to do this, his superior officer being present.

Mrs. Fraser was called and her story was heard. She threw some reflections upon the management, found fault with the amount of fatty food supplied, defended herself against the charge of gossiping, affirmed her faithfulness to duty, and declared her intention both of clearing up any misapprehensions upon her status and of leaving the service if the Department should so decide. No one could help admiring her able defense. She was dignified and logical throughout. The Principal however regarded it as a tissue of incorrect statements and so the matter ended. As it was more of a personal dispute than an offence in which the Department was concerned, the matter was left in abeyance until further investigation was requested or ordered, but I see no reason why the lady's salary should be withheld insomuch as the work assigned her by the Department was without doubt very well done.

Sir,

As we have been passing through troubles of an unusual character lately it is considered advisable to let you know something of what has been happening in these last days.

You have already been advised that the principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School passed away on the 22nd instant. He fell ill on a return journey from Kenora at Ash Rapids. Fortunately he had brought a nurse to the school at the time and she gave him first aid until his death and nursed him carefully afterwards up to the time of death. Her services were invaluable.

Our Dr. Ferguson followed him out from here and treated him at the school and then returned and fell sick himself. He was compelled to go to the hospital at Kenora with his wife who was also sick. Word of the growing need of medical aid at the school was sent to Mr. Inspector Semmens and he reported it to Dr. Grain who, because he had made arrangements to visit Fort Alexander was unable to give the school personal attention. It was left for Mr. Semmens to get what assistance he could. He engaged a Dr. Henderson on the 17th instant but the next day he was laid up with the disease himself and could not go. On the 18th a Dr. Yule was engaged and he left Winnipeg on the morning of the 19th and could not find a boat until the 20th. He found the Principal practically beyond medical aid but did what he could for the dying man for the sick children and the sick Indians on the reserve. The Dr. returned to Winnipeg on the night of the 25th. Meantime Dr. Ferguson thinking that he might be recovering got up from a sick bed and hurried after Dr. Yule but the Principal was dead when he arrived at the school. The body was brought in on the 23rd and was buried in the Kenora cemetery on the 25th instant, the Rev. Dr. Murray of Toronto conducted the services both at the undertaking rooms and at the grave.

Mrs. Matthews has gone back to the school to pack her goods and will shortly leave for the West to stay with the parents of her late husband. I can assure you this has been an anxious time for us all, but the news from the school is cheering as the disease abates. What is called the Spanish Flu is at present very prevalent in the Kenora Boarding School and on the Rat Portage Reserve. No deaths have been reported from the school here but out on the reserve two grown persons and four children have already died. We are feeding them and doing all we can to aid them but the weather is bad and at the doctor's last visit yesterday conditions were more hopeful.

Dr. Ferguson has certainly proved himself to be a hero in his devotion to duty. He has no thought of his personal interest and has given the Indians every possible care and attention.

Indian Agent McKenzie has been ever active and faithful to the last duty. He has spent time and energy freely in hours and after hours in the endeavour to meet every demand made upon his judgment, his time and his resources. Two more faithful officers could not be found anywhere than the Medical Officer and the Agent at this point.

Mr. Inspector Semmens ran down when he heard of the death of Mr. Matthews to see if he could give any help and to represent the Department at the funeral returning to Winnipeg Saturday 26th.

Owing to the time of year we have heard no news from the reserves out on the Lake and it is impossible for us to fetch them just now. The Savanne Agency has not sent any report or sickness or made any appeals for assistance so far.

(Sgd.) R. S. McKenzie, Ind. Agt.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR SIMMS ON THE CECILIA JEFFREY BOARDING SCHOOL.

In November the Church sent in Mr. P.T. Martin a lawyer from Williamsport, Indiana who is also a clergyman of the Congregational Church. He was temporarily employed for a period of six months as Principal of Cecilia Jeffrey school. He is on trial and if he proves his worth, may be permanently employed after his probation expires.

Meantime, Rev. Mr. McQuarrie (Kenora) controls the finances and keeps the accounts while Mr. Martin is local manager. This arrangement is probably perhaps the best that could be made under the circumstances but will not do as a permanent procedure. The Principal must have a free hand and must be supported by the authority of the Church and the Indian Dept., otherwise he cannot take that deep interest in his charge which is necessary to success. A divided responsibility weakens any enterprise.

Now as to my own impressions of Mr. Martin, I have to say that a considerable portion of my time was taken up in conversing with him so that I might estimate his fitness for the position and be able to represent his case to the Department in an intelligent manner. His training and experience as a lawyer will no doubt enable him to judge questions from all points of view so that his conclusions are likely to be well thought out and action based upon them to be definite and wise. He has a good deal of self-possession, has a good temper, is firm yet gentle. He is a person of good address, pleasant in manners and disposed to be amiable and conciliatory. He is a practical man, knows a good deal about machinery, is not afraid of work, is a good manager and looks toward profitable and permanent results.

I knew little of his history but his position as a clergyman should be a guarantee of his moral worth. His addresses to the children and to the staff give evidence of an unusual ability to direct and counsel receptive minds. He has instituted a system of detention so that boys who violate the rules of propriety are shut up for a short time in small compartments and lightly fed but immediately released when they show signs of penitence and promise amendment. So far the children are quite attached to him. No single member of the staff has been discontented though ample opportunity was afforded. The chiefs of 30 and 47 expressed themselves in most complimentary terms. Old misunderstandings seem to be disappearing like snow in springtime. I have great hopes for the future. Should the Church decide to make his appointment permanent and allow him to pursue a progressive policy he is willing to continue and I am convinced that he will in a short while be able to show better results than the school has ever known.

Report dated, February 6th, 1917.
GENERAL REMARKS,

1. I am convinced that more agricultural work should be done and am sure that the soil can be found within easy reach.

2. In order to supply the school with milk and butter more stock is an absolute necessity. With this, dairying can be taught to the great advantage of pupils.

3. At the present time a man with a pony and sleigh goes 20 miles to Inwood station for the mails once a week. The mail might be brought from Winnipeg over the Water District Railroad in a school bag so that a trip of 5 miles over and 5 miles back might suffice for this purpose each week, instead of 40 miles per week as at present. By this method, mail could be received three times each week.

6. The freighting of school supplies from Kenora is expensive and takes the Principal away from home a great deal. Why not purchase in Winnipeg freight out to the end of steel at Waugh and have only ten miles to haul it instead of 80. That is to Waugh and return is but ten miles while to Kenora and return is 80.

Dear Captain Edwards,

Your last letter referring to the matter of Willie Sinclair and Granny Green received.

I have taken the matter up with Counsellor Indian Joe, a brother of Granny Green, and we have been able to arrange for their accommodation in a house near to his residence. This we believe is the best that can be done for Willie Sinclair. There is no doubt that with the return of spring that he may recover.

Referring to Granny Green, she is dependent on Big Joe her brother who is well or in a worse or less crippled. I am arranging to supply them with the necessary supplies in the way of tea, sugar, lard, and flour. We have cared for Granny Green all winter and she will be dependent upon either the government or the school for supplies.

In regard to the other boy Joseph Carpenter, it will not be necessary to make any arrangements as I fear he cannot last very much longer. He is in a critical condition.

The third case referred to is that of Velma Kabentrew, she is an exceptionally bright girl and we would all be sorry to lose her. I will try to do the best I can in the way of providing means for open air treatment.

Referring to the matter of wood, I am pleased to hear that you have been able to get at least a promise in the matter of the disposal. The carpenter from Olympia Mine was here today and there will be no trouble in our disposing of it. Regarding the matter of price, we paid $2.50 a cord that figure covers the cost of cutting and purchase of wood. It will cost another 60 cents to haul to the Lake Shore and 30 cents for storage which means that we could not sell at least than $3.00 a cord to cover expenses. I believe it might be possible for us to haul to the Lake Shore during the summer although I am not particularly anxious for the job, as we can well afford to hold the wood.

I have got myself into considerable trouble with the Board over cutting this wood but I am confident was fully confident that the investment would pay for itself.

In regard to the question of launch and school repair, I have not heard anything as yet outside of the fact that the Committee will visit the school to advise us regarding the action of the Board in this respect. Mention has been made of the fact that we shall remain in the building for the year 1923 when the government will build a new school with a better location.

I still adhere to the suggestion that we have already made in this matter and I am fully persuaded if only the Church and Government will consider our suggestion that it will be in the interest of our Indians from these two reserves, without receiving a child as yet from N.W.Angle we have new born children I believe on the roll we have three others that we expect to go after tramping. There is no need to move the building merely. For what might be its gain in the feeding of stock and greater convenience in handling supplies. A little work and will guarantee to cut down the feeding stock 65% of what it is at the present time. We have already started work and it will be easily possible for us to grow all the corn and hay we need right on the school land.

As to the question of freight I fail to see that we are going to gain very much providing of course that we could procure a suitable launch.

Again I am not in favour of closing the school without due consideration being given to the feelings of the Indians in this matter. When other Reserves closed their doors to the question of a School, the Indians on these Reserves gave to the Church the opening that they asked for by way of trying to prove that Education is the value of education. They have stood by the school. There isn't a child with but one exception of school age but is attending school.

We need a school in fact two or three to do our duty to those hundreds of children that at the present time have no school to attend. It will be impossible for us to accept any of the children that may desire to attend the school following Treaty, and I know there a great many who are planning to do so. If the Church and the Government would only give us this assurance that a new
school would be built without in any way affecting the work at Shoal Lake I would find some way of enlarging our dormitories and dining room myself. It would not cost so very much for I would do all the work myself, with the help of but two men and the boys at school. However, of course with the uncertainty of things we shall simply have to refuse unless we should decide to convert the second floor and convert it into a dormitory for the big boys. Personally I do not for a moment think the Government will build a new school even if they should so to replace the present building for the next 5 or 6 years. I have no doubt but what a sum of money will be voted upon my way of putting a suitable foundation for the interior support of this building, and I am satisfied with this, there are numbers of schools that will be in far greater need than what we will for the next ten or eight or nine years.

I am pleased to report that we have a new Teacher, also that the boy taken to St. Roches Hospital has returned his health has improved although he still has a slight discharge from the eye. I am uncertain as to his age possibly you could fill this in for us.

There is a matter here that should be attended to at Treaty No. 044 Beatrice Po papi nais eck, She has two illegitimate children and no means of support. I believe that the father is Sam Keeick (the Chief's son) She comes to the school for support and some steps ought to be taken in the settlement of her case.

This is our last mail I expect to be in Kenora when the Lake is clear.

Yours truly,

At the meeting of the Executive of our Board of Home Missions and Social Service, held recently, it was agreed, after conference with the Women's Missionary Society:

1st. To again ask the Indian Department to erect a new building to take care of the children in the Lake of the Woods district, the building to be located on another site, preferably where there are farming facilities.

2nd. To request the Indian Department to make such expenditure as may be necessary on the present Cecilia Jeffrey plant, to make the building habitable and comfortable.

3rd. To ask the Government to provide a new boat, also a boat house.

You may wonder why the Executive is asking for repairs on the old school, while at the same time they are urging the erection of a new building on another site. This request is made as the result of recommendations from the Presbytery of Winnipeg and the Women's Missionary Society. It was argued that it will take a year or two to complete the new building and that in the meantime, the staff and children should be comfortable.

The heating plant and the plumbing system need overhauling. The lighting system is poor and there should be some incidental repairs - mine, out houses, etc., and a new boat is an absolute necessity. At present, the only means of getting in and out of Cecilia Jeffrey is by a disappearing-propeller boat that was purchased by the members of the staff.

If the new building is to be ready within a year, we would, of course, expect that a minimum of expenditure should be made on the buildings - just sufficient to make them habitable and sanitary.

Some of our representatives in Manitoba are prepared to recommend two schools for the Lake of the Woods district. They claim there are plenty of children to fill two buildings. If I mistake not, the Agent, Mr. [illegible], shares this view.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

19th November

Dear Mrs. Clarke,

I delayed answering your letters until I had an opportunity to visit Selina Jeffrey School.

My Messier and his wife arrived, and I was with them on Friday and Saturday morning, and we thoroughly discussed the several matters on which he desired information.

You seem to be under the impression that I am not in favour of the Department spending money on the School, but I can assure you the contrary is the fact, as if the Church Authorities do not or cannot install electric light, the Department should do so, as the danger is very great of having a fire which would have very disastrous effects, the frame buildings would go in no time.

You inform me Mr. Cookson spent over $7000.00 on repairs and equipment in the last two years, if this is so I cannot understand where the money has gone, he always appeared to be very economical, I cannot understand how it was there are no books to show his expenditure.

I was not aware that the Government were responsible for the buildings and equipment and the Church for the payment of staff and clothing of pupils.

If this is so it appears to me that we are responsible for the installation of the electric light plant, but I will ascertain this from the Department as they informed me some time ago that they considered the Church Authorities should pay for the installation of an electric light plant.

As regards the launch, I feel sure you could not have obtained a more suitable one, providing you have a capable Engineer to run the engine, and whatever kind of a boat you had, you would require a barge, Mr. Cookson informed me that the one he built (which is a very good one) only cost $75 for material, the labour being supplied by himself and the boys.

The boat you got cost us more than the $4300 charged the School.

I will communicate with my Department and ascertain if they are willing to bear more of the expenses of running this School, but as regards a new School, at the present time in the Kenora Agency, I think although you say you are due one, that it will be difficult to get the Department to see this as in my Savanna Agency I have over 700 children of school age without any School, it would therefore not be right for me to ask for another School for you, until their needs had been attended to.

As regards the isolation ward, I discussed this with Mr. Messier, and he considering the matter.
(Mrs Clarke, 2)

I am informed an electrician from Schumaker-Gray in Winnipeg visited the School and made an estimate of the costs of installing and wiring, so presume something will be done soon by someone.

If the School was removed from Shoal Lake to Kewatin, we should have great difficulty in getting the parents to allow their children to attend. The School we have in Kenora are always wishing they were further away, owing to the difficulty in keeping children, they are always running away, and being brought back by the Constable and others. This never occurs at Shoal Lake.

It was too bad I could not meet you last summer, but it was at Treaty time and I was unable to get away, however I hope you will make a trip soon when I may have the pleasure of your acquaintance.

Reduction in grant. The Department deducted the two weeks holidays allowed, it was not my fault as I O.K. ed the returns as originally sent in, but it was justified from Ottawa, and if the Department has not already allowed you the two weeks, perhaps they will do so if you ask them, although you understand there are rules set down that must be maintained.

I was very sorry to have to send the returns back to the School for revision, but was compelled to.

Re your grant of $168 per pupil, this is a very large grant, and I doubt if there is any other School in Canada under our Department getting a larger one, I always understood the grant was only $148.

Mr Freeman is taking very great interest in the School, and the Staff are very favorably impressed with him, as is also Mr Macdonald, Mr Freeman informs me he will be able to visit the School again about New Year and I will try and arrange one of my visits so that we can be there together.

Three of the School children are in Hospital in Winnipeg and we are sending them back on Wednesday next.

Mr Macdonald informed me there is a large quantity of material at the School, purchased by the late Principal, for the alterations to the building, which he will use up.

Providing the electric light plant is installed, and the wiring and fixtures set up, he does not think at the present time much more is necessary.

The second teacher Miss Lament has left and Miss Bennett who I understand was previously at the School, has taken her place.

I should be glad if the Church could suggest or do something for the pupils leaving the School when discharged, it seems a pity they should go back to their old life again, after the work done on their behalf at the School. Perhaps you could get suggestions from the new Principal.

With kind regards,

Yours faithfully,

Mrs Adelaide Clarke,
W.M.C Presbyterian Church,
Toronto, Ont.,

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

On July 29th and 30th I visited the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. The institution is situated on a peninsula in Shoal Lake. The postoffice address is Indian Bay, Man., and the express and freight agent is in care of the G.H.&N.R.R., Man. Mr. Mensies is a kindly type, but I was not impressed by his ability as an organizer. His wife has no sympathy for the work and I believe he is the actual head of the institution. She is not the proper type for institutional life; is matron but cannot handle the staff. The outside man, Mr. Gibson, is a splendid chap with children. He is responsible for the small farm, the carpentering and engineering end of the work. They allow a week-end holiday for the pupils that live close to the school. I discouraged this practice.

The main building needed paint, but material was supplied a year ago and the work was about to be undertaken. The building is badly cut up by alterations and is not suitable for purposes of Indian education. The heating system is inadequate - there are three separate units. The lighting plant is working well. The water intake has had to be rebuilt; church funds are being used.

I promised to send a little athletic equipment and to give favourable consideration to requisitions for material for Art. One of the teachers is a splendid artist and some of the pupils are showing excellent progress.

The school purposes changing the balcony to an infirmary and making alterations in the present sick-room. It can be undertaken by day labour, under the supervision of the staff, provided that one skilled carpenter is engaged and the materials allowed. They will really need more than $400 which has been promised, I believe. If the Church would furnish the rest of the money, I believe the Department should allow $600 for this work. I propose to examine the correspondence and write the agent.
As you are aware, we get most of our supplies over the G.W.W.D. Ry. at Waugh. This necessitates our approach via Indian Bay, a sheet of navigable water about 14 miles by 3½ miles, from one end of which Winnipeg gets its water supply. The Railway and waterway belong to the city. We have received instructions from the Superintendent of the system that next spring we must cease the use of Indian Bay and approach Waugh via Snowshoe Bay and a so-called canal, connecting it with the west end of Indian Bay for drainage purposes. Snowshoe Bay is not navigable for a row-boat at present, much less for a launch of any kind, being very shallow and infested with weeds. So much for the situation. Presuming on your interest in our school, I want to ask you to ascertain from the proper Department whether the Government has authorized or could authorize the City of Winnipeg or its officials to close against navigation a body of water such as the above, whose entrance is three or four hundred yards wide.

(Sd.) A. D. Menzies.

Dear Dr. Scott:

I have yours of April 17th if which you ask if the resolution we sent you on the 15th concerning an isolation hospital at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School has to do with "an isolation hospital for pupils of the school at the proposed new site."

That is not the suggestion of our Women's Missionary Society. They feel that the Tubercular Hospital for the Indians should not be near the new school. Our representatives in Winnipeg contend that the Principal's residence at the present Cecilia Jeffrey School could be used effectively as a hospital. It is a commodious building with three or four rooms upstairs as well as downstairs. It has running water, toilet, etc. It would not be an expensive matter to fit it out as an isolation hospital.

Our District Superintendent for the Manitoba Conference is strongly of the opinion that something should be done for the tubercular Indians in that locality. We will not require the building when the new school is ready for occupation.

If you did not regard the Principal's residence as adequate for hospital purposes, after you have the new school erected, the present Boarding School could be used.

Those who brought the matter before us were of the opinion that at first, a resident nurse might be sufficient with a visit from a medical assistant from Winnipeg twice a week.

If you find that the Principal's residence is adequate for the purpose, the Women's Missionary Society feel that the Government should have the use of it as their contribution to this most needy cause.

Sir,

On Friday the 4th inst., we inspected the Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School at Shoal Lake, and there would seem to be a lack of good feeling between the staff and the principal. I believe the church authorities should be informed and the matter investigated, so that things would run more smoothly to the advantage of staff and Indians alike.

In response to a request of the principal, Dr. Ferguson removed tonsils from three pupils named Tully, who are white. Their father is employed by the Greater Winnipeg Water District Railway at Waugh, Man., and I understand that payment is being made for their board and education. The teacher herself, who has been at the school for fifteen years, is averse to their presence, and I do not think for my own part that they should attend, since there are many Indian children on Lake of the Woods who could attend if they were properly recruited.

In regard to holidays, the principal tells me that he is giving six weeks, as he did last year. I think this is all right, although Dr. Ferguson feels that owing to the amount of Tuberculosis in that neighbourhood the vacation should be extended.

Nurse Reid, who is paid by the Department, asked me if she could have the same holidays as the children. I informed her that this would be quite satisfactory provided there were no sick children to be attended. In discussing the matter, the principal did not think she should have so long. I should be glad to have instructions confirming my recommendation.

The attitude of the principal towards the staff is that of an autocrat. Neither the staff nor the missionary are allowed to enter the school by the front door. The nurse had her first intimation of the operation on the Tully children when Dr. Ferguson told her he had been asked to operate. I would therefore recommend a change of principal, with a temporary appointment if the difficulties between the United and Presbyterian churches forbid anything more permanent.

Dear Dr. Edmonson:

I regret that it is my duty to draw to your attention a recent report from Mr. Indian Agent Edwards, of Kenora. Following a general inspection of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School on the 4th instant, he reports in part as follows: "There would seem to be a lack of good feeling between the staff and the principal. I might add that the Superintendent of Indian Education visited this school in July, 1924, and reported that he was not impressed with Mr. Menzies' ability. Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th instant and in reply beg to state that the Indian Act provides for the compulsory attendance at school of physically fit children from 7 to 15 years of age. The rigid enforcement of this section is undertaken by the Department only when it is considered advisable. I am not satisfied that drastic action to enforce attendance at the Lake of the Woods Indian children should be taken at the present time. Serious consideration to such action may be given when our building programme is completed.

I further doubt the advisability of making temporary arrangements for the accommodation of boys outside of the main building at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. A pupilage of 95 is allowed, and, to earn a grant for this number, an enrolment of 99 or 100 would be necessary. Sir,

I beg to submit herewith my report in the matter of Mildred Martin, #49 Shoal Lake Band No. 40, reported by the principal of Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School as being a common prostitute and a menace to morality on the reserve and in the neighbourhood of the school. Attached hereto is the letter from Mr. Menzies setting forth his complaint, in consequence whereof I made a journey to Shoal Lake to investigate this along with other matters.

On arrival at the school I immediately went into Mildred's case with Mr. and Mrs. Menzies, and gathered from their expressed opinions that she was a sort of moral leper whose activities could not be curtailed except in a detention home. I was advised that I should be armed before going to interview Mildred and her parents, especially if I should suggest taking her to Winnipeg for mental observation (this course being indicated by police reports). However, I found the girl quite ready to discuss her position, after she had recovered from the preliminary breakdown and shame attending my appearance. She admitted several indiscretions so openly that I was inclined to consider her rather unbalanced or brazen, until further conversation gained her confidence, when she expressed her entire willingness to go to Winnipeg to see Mr. Bunn and to find, if possible, some sanctuary where she would not be subjected to overwhelming temptations. She admitted she was none too strong in the face of temptation, and her story coincides with subsequent investigation which showed that having once got on the wrong track she was hounded by a certain type of young loafer among the Indians.

Accordingly, I took Mildred to Waugh, Kan., that same night, in company with Miss Reid, the nurse, so that we might get the train for Winnipeg in the morning. Before leaving the school Miss Reid was instructed by Mrs. Menzies to make Mildred sleep on the floor, and to lock the door. In this connection I would refer you to the last paragraph of Mr. Menzies' letter.

I took Mildred to Winnipeg the next day, but arrived too late to enable us to see Mr. Bunn, so I registered Mildred at the Y.W.C.A., putting her on her honour to be there when I should have to find her. She was under no restraint, and I found her there whenever I required to see her. Desirous of neutral opinion, I took her to see my mother and sisters who both concluded that she was quite normal, but perhaps too young for her years, and undeveloped in the ability to protect herself from the effects of physical maturity.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora.
On Monday, January 11th, Mildred and I went to see Mr. Bunn at his office. He had a long talk with Mildred, and stated his determination to take no steps involving her detention and the stamping of her as a degenerate, but he wrote a letter to Mr. Menzies, commending Mildred to his kindness and charity, suggesting that she be received at the school in some capacity and given a helping hand, since her case seemed to provide a good opportunity for the exercise of a clergyman's holy office.

On Wednesday, January 13th, Mildred and I returned to Shoal Lake, taking with us her tiny niece Elizabeth Martin, who had been in St. Boniface Hospital with a broken leg. Mildred gave her every possible attention so that the child arrived at the school feeling as comfortable as when she left the hospital.

Mildred's reception was not attended with the killing of any fatted calf, and Mr. Menzies refused to take her into the school in any capacity, and suggested that I send her back to the reserve, claiming that none of the pupils would have anything to do with her, and that he was glad of it. To return her to the reserve would have been to expose her to the former vicious circumstances, so I took the matter entirely into my own hands. The next day I sent Mildred home with her father, to see her mother, telling her I would call for her in a short time. This I did, and brought her back to the school for the night, to the evident dislike of Mrs. Menzies.

Next morning, at seven o'clock, I took Mildred from the school. She received a parcel from Miss Reid and Miss Brodie, and a request from nearly all the girls to write to them. Charley Green had his pony waiting, and we came to Ingolf and so to Kenora, where Mildred is at present, helping my wife with her housework, and giving satisfaction. We propose to pay her as we would pay a white girl for the same work, unless yourself or the Department should formulate some different plan.

While at Shoal Lake I ordered two Indians to return to their own reserves. These Indians had been concerned in Mildred's case, and had been hanging around the school at nights, with the permission of the principal, who complained to me that young Indians had given chewing stuff to very young boys, and stood outside the building at night and whistled to the girls in the dormitory, causing a stampede to the windows. I pointed out that the school site had been surrendered, and that he was empowered to keep such visitors away. He admitted that he knew this to be so, but apparently he had not utilized his powers in this direction. He told me that one girl pupil had complained that Norman Kelly had made advances to her and had attempted her virtue. Notwithstanding this, I found Norman Kelly visiting the school.
In the course of my enquiries I discovered that male visitors to the school were making amorous advances to the girl pupils, and I took from one Indian who confessed to this practice a letter he had received in reply and which is attached to this report. In view of information received from Mildred since her establishment here I expect to bring to light even worse conditions than those already revealed.

Discipline at the school seems to consist of an even mixture of laxity and of severe repression. As the pupil's attached letter shows, pupils are permitted to go home for the week-end, although the principal realizes the dangers involved, and when a pupil falls from grace as in Mildred's case he suggests that she be placed in a detention home and branded as a Magdalene. In considering the conditions at the school one finds it difficult to absolve the principal from contribution to her downfall, and his refusal to rise to Mr. Bunn's kindly proposal is barely in keeping with the professed philosophy of Christ, as enjoined on the clergy. It is not decently pagan.

Your obedient servant,

Hector M. Angus.

On Friday I went by train from St Boniface to Waugh on route to make my usual inspection of the Cecilia Jeffrey School. At Waugh I met the Rev John A. Cormie, District Superintendent of the United Church who had been into the School to audit the books.

He informed me there was a certain amount of unrest at the School, between the staff and the Principal, this I knew, and have informed you of it, some time ago.

Mr Cormie said nothing could be done at the present time as the Continuing Presbyterians were taking over the School, and no changes could be made until the organisation was ready to take over.

Some of the staff complained to me of certain matters, but I informed them of my conversation with Dr Cormie, and that this was entirely a Church matter, and things would no doubt be remedied at an early date.

I also let them know it was entirely a Church matter and nothing to do with our Department.

I was informed that the Principal and his wife had gone to extremes, as previously they had been very strict disciplinarians, they were now too easy, and in consequence the children were hard to control.

Miss Brodie, the teacher informed me she had asked the Principal's wife for a loaf of bread for an old dying woman (Mrs Green) Mrs Lenzie refused, so Miss Brodie asked if she could purchase a loaf for the old woman, this she was allowed to do, and paid for same out of her own pocket. Miss Reid, the Nurse, informed me she had asked for eggs for some sick children, but was refused, although there were plenty at the School, but she was allowed to purchase some herself from the School stock, which she did and supplied them at her own expense to the children.

I have authority as per Departmental letter 35-129 of 24th ultimo to purchase 5 tons of hay for the North West Angle Band #33, and as Shoal Lake Band #40 had no hay for their oxen, I asked the Principal of the School, if he would sell us some, he agreed, but said it would cost $19.00 per ton f.o.b. Waugh, as I found out afterwards the hay costs the school, $15.00 per ton and not $1.25 freight. The Indians were very hard up and I gave the Principal authority to issue a small amount of provision as relief. The staff inform me that the Principal even charges the Indians for clothing sent by the Church people for the Indians. He also runs a store at the School, and his prices are as high or higher than that charged by the store at Waugh. He claims that if he charged less the storekeeper at Waugh would object. I informed him that according to the act he should apply for permission to trade according to sec. 42 & 31 of the Indian Act, but he did not seem willing to do this.

There is no doubt this store is a convenience to the Indians but the goods should be at least sold at a fair price. This would make for better feelings between the School and the parents and assist recruiting.

The Principal is more of a hard headed business man than a Principal or Missionary, and I am informed
He practically never visits the Indians on the Reserves, although they live only a few minutes walk from the School.

Dr Cormie informs me that when the late Principal Mr Cookson left, the School was in debt about $1500 and that the present principal wiped this off and is now somewhere about $3000 or $4000.00 ahead. This does not look reasonable, I made enquiries and the children appear to be well fed and nourished, and it seems to me the surplus has been made from trading with the Indians, as well as Mr Menzies being a close business man, if he had used any surplus towards helping some of the poor Indians he would have had better feelings between the Indians and himself, a large amount of relief I understand was always previously given by the School to the destitutes.

There was a certain amount of immorality going on at the School, but I do not suggest this was the fault of the Principal, I had the offenders up before me, in front of the Principal and they were severely reprimanded.

All the above information is for your file, as I do not think anything can be done until the Presbyterian Church takes over, and make their own arrangements for their staff.

Dr Cormie asked me to inform him, the amount of grant per capita the school was receiving, and when this had been raised to the present amount, I should be glad therefore if you would kindly send him this information as soon as possible, also notifying me at the same time. Dr Cormie's address is:

Dear Mr. Perrier:

A certain member of our staff, for reasons best known to herself, has adopted a course of action ruinous to the harmony and cooperation so necessary to the work of our school. She has estranged from her the entire staff by language and conduct which I will not attempt to characterize. I have found it necessary to give her a month's notice as provided for in our agreements.

The air has cleared somewhat today, but I understand she has appealed to you and to the W.M.S. Board of Toronto, hence this letter. The Secretary of the Board will no doubt respond by our next weekly mail; should you wish an enquiry I should be pleased to have Capt. Edwards pay us a visit and make if desired a thorough investigation. Accordingly I will not burden you with details but may note that one cause of the outward storm can be traced to Labor Day. We had a very heavy fall of rain on the night preceding and mud and water lay everywhere; rain still threatened and I felt it was a day quite unfit for a holiday here as we must be watchful re wet feet and consequent colds. I told the teachers to call school and we would have a holiday a little later when it could be enjoyed. This may not be strictly legal but I know you
We are interested in conserving the health of the children under our charge and will agree that there is an unwritten law that should on occasion take precedence.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Capt. Edwards that he may be informed regarding the situation.

Yours faithfully

Dear Mrs. Strachan:

With reference to the last paragraph of your letter of the first instant, concerning the site for the new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, I wish to inform you the Department does not consider it advisable to consult the Rev. March 14, 1928.

Dear Mrs. Strachan:

In reply to your letter of the 12th instant, I have to state that the decision to have another principal for the new institution was made before the division of the Indian work between the United Church and the Presbyterian Church in Canada and that it was the wish of both the Department and the Mission Board that the change be made. I may say that Mr. and Mrs. Menzies have shown lack of ability to properly handle the staff of an institution and there have been several reports from responsible department officers concerning unsatisfactory conditions at the Cecilia Jeffrey School. I regret that I have to request you to nominate another reverend gentleman for the principalship of the new school.

The Reverend Mr. Menzies may not be aware of the exact nature of this decision; but, undoubtedly, he knows that the Department is not satisfied with his services.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

I am in receipt of a copy of your letter #129-3-I of May 30 to the principal of the Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Residential School re the resignation of Miss Besale Clare, nurse.

On my visit to the school on May 21st, Mr. Macdonald informed me that Miss Clare was leaving as she had received the offer of a much higher position. The principal was deducting two weeks salary in lieu of notice, this money to go to the school. I informed him that as Miss Clare was paid by the Department, I did not think they would agree to any deduction from her salary and as I was on Treaty payments, I asked him to try to arrange for someone to fill her place, subject to approval by the Department. He now writes me that he has engaged Miss Matheson, who has had the following training: Eye Infirmary, Glasgow, 2 years; Northern Infirmary, Inverness, 1 year; General Hospital, Winnipeg, Obstetrical, 3 months. In addition to this she has had 4 or 5 years experience. Miss Matheson came to Canada last fall and started duty on the 1st of May.

We have not been able to see Miss Matheson as yet as we are now on Treaty payments and shall be away until the 1st of July.

On the principal's recommendation, I would therefore ask that her appointment be approved.

Vouchers for the principal's expenses in this connection will be forwarded as soon as possible after we return from Treaty payments.

Your obedient servant,

For your information is quoted below what transpired at the Conference of Chiefs and Councilors of the various Bands in the Kenora and Savanne Agencies held at Kenora on the 16th and 17th July, 1928, in connection with Indian Education.

I promised them that I would submit their statements to the Department for its information and consideration.

The Conference started about 10 o'clock on Monday, July 16th, by Mr. Paget, who informed the Indians that he came from Ottawa to listen to anything they had to say to him as regards complaints they might have.

Chief William Gardner of the Wabigoon Band opened the meeting, by saying that he was glad to see Mr. Paget and hoped he would give them plenty of time to talk as they did not often have a representative from Ottawa and the Indians had a great deal to say.

Mr. Paget stated he would be willing to stay two days and listen to them, or longer if it was found necessary. This satisfied everybody.

Chief Gardner, Wabigoon Band. For my part, I have not paid anyone to write for me as I like to keep my money in my pocket and if I find out the Agent does not do as I want or find out things for me when I ask him, I might then go to someone else, or go direct to the Department, but I would be sure to go to somebody who is in authority and not outsiders. As regard the schools he thinks the same as the other Chiefs and thinks a great deal of what the Government is doing to educate the Indian children and is very thankful to the Government for helping them. But he has a grievance against the Roman Catholic School. His wife and one of his sons have been in school but he does not feel that they have learned anything and what little the boys know he has taught them, particularly as regards hunting and trapping, and he has had hard work to teach them to trap as they were fairly old when they left school and should have learned this when they were young, but they were in school and there the children did not learn anything about hunting. The children could not read or write well when leaving school. The youngest one of the boys went to school when he was 7 and he is now 17. Surely he should have been able to read and write now. What is taught at the school mostly is to pray and not to learn to read and write and that is why the children are backward. Since leaving the school the ministers or priests have not come to see them. Mr. Sanderson does. He is glad to know that there is a Protestant School being built at Kenora and he looks on the schools not for religious purposes only. He said that is a question for each person to
decide for himself. Is it possible to teach children a better way to earn a living? He hears at the Cecelia Jeffrey they are taught trades. This is not done at the Catholic School. The boys in leaving school are not fitted to take up work in town and make a living. Could not they be taught some trades?

Mr. Paget said he would write to the Department what the Indians said about the schools.

Chief Gardner said he hoped to see the new school filled with children and when the children were at the two schools in Kenora the parents would come to see them occasionally, but now the Indians have no Reserve or camping ground at Kenora and no house to live in when they came in the Winter or Summer. If they camped on a white man's land they might be and are often sent away. Could not some place be got for the Indians to stay?

Mr. Paget then said that the Agent had been speaking to him about this and the Department would see if anything could be done. The Agent has spoken to Mr. Paget each year about this and the matter would be taken up.

Chief Kejick wanted to know what had been done about the old school, Cecelia Jeffrey School, at Shoal Lake. Mr. Paget informed him that the school would be closed and a very much better one built at Kenora. Chief Kejick said the school should be left as it is as there are enough children at Shoal Lake and Nor'west Angle to fill the present school. When the school was first built there, the other Chiefs were not in favor of it, but the Shoal Lake Indians were and that was why the school was built there, and the Indians were told that as long as the Indians were there, the school would be there, and they wished to have it kept there. He said he had 30 children from his own Reserve now attending the school, or would be able to attend shortly.

Mr. Paget said the Department were building a new school at Kenora as the Cecelia Jeffrey School was not large enough and was owned by the Church, and not the Department. Also that a larger school near town would cost much less to maintain and being nearer town the children would have a better chance to learn the white man's ways, etc.

Chief Kejick, Shoal Lake Band No. 39, said he agreed with what the other Chiefs had said about the children. That they did not know how to make a living when they left school and would like trades taught. In the old days trapping was different. Now the only way the Indians can make a living is to work like the white man and owing to the furs going through white men trapping and the raising of waters, it made it harder for the Indians each year to make a living.

Chief Kejick said he had eight children from his Reserve in the school and when the children left they did not know anything and could hardly speak English. They work hard to see that the children attended every day and one of the troubles was that the children were made to work at cutting wood around the school and not in the classroom, and even the very young ones did this. He thinks this is wrong as they go to school to learn to read, write and speak English. He had no fault to find with the new school being built and would
do his best to send the children from the Reserve. He said when the children left school there was nothing done for them, not even given a blanket. When the school was built they promised that when these pupils left school they should have a sewing machine or lumber for a house, or something given them to enable them to earn a living.

Mr. Paget promised to look into this for them and let the Agent know if anything could be done.

Chief Black Hawk, North West Angle Band, No. 33, said he was glad to hear about the school and had sent some children to the Cecelia Jeffrey School. He could not understand why the Indians were not consulted first as to where the schools should be built, and he was not in favor of it being built at Kenora. It should have been built at the South end of the lake nearer their Reserve. Mr. Paget said the attendance of school children was compulsory the same as the white children if the Department insisted on them going, but up to the present time had not been compelled. The Department could not build schools near all the Reserves and had to decide on the best positions. The Department could not please everybody and the Indians came to Kenora more than any other place, and could see their children once or twice a year.

Chief Black Hawk said he did not understand the school was going to be built right close to the town but now thought it would be alright after hearing the explanation. He hoped the Department would get some land where the Indians could camp and have a house where they could stay to be called an Indian House.

Chief Thunder, Buffalo Bay Reserve, speaking through Chief Gardner. I won't promise to send all our children to school, but I shall let the Department build a school and I would like to see the Indians use it. Can all Indians send their children to this school?

Agent Edwards. Roman Catholic children must go to the Roman Catholic School and Protestant Children to the Protestant school and pagans can go to either school.

Councillor Jim Kahkeeway said he had a girl who had been in school four years and she was deaf. Could she be discharged. Agent Edwards promised to look into this.

Chief Williamson said that old man Sinclair had a girl in school who had bad eyes, and the only trouble she had was when she was in the classroom. The Chief wanted this girl discharged. Agent Edwards said this girl had been to see a Specialist in Winnipeg last Fall and he would get the particulars, and if the Doctor said she should be discharged, he would see that this was done.

Chief Jim Williams informed the Agent that it was reported to him that at the Kenora school the children are made to kneel sometimes for hours at a time. This is called "sitting punishment" but is not really sitting but kneeling. The Chief thinks this is cruel and should not be allowed. Agent Edwards promised to put this in his report and looking into it.
October 17, 1928.

Mr. Fen

May I thank the Women's Missionary Society (the Centenary) in Canada for inviting me to consider the position of Principal of the Indian Boarding School at Lac La Biche.

My many years experience as a teacher both in Canada and the U.S.A. has fitted me for such a position and the Board when they wrote me also many experiences indicate character and reputation are of the best kind.

Later, a letter from the Women's Society informed me that it was possible to be appointed to the Interim Board of Education, but no such thing being done, the Board was dissolved and a new Board was appointed to take charge.

It was the case of Mr. Wilson, a former teacher, whose name appeared on the list of those who had been dismissed by the Board. It was found that he had been dismissed for cause of misconduct.

Any complaints had been made to him as the only person who could be expected to undertake to correct the mischief caused by his conduct. You will look through the file for the records of all subsequent disclosures concerning this fact. It is evident that there are two stories, and further discovery of facts would have been necessary on my part. I felt certain
particularly in protecting the Indians under my supervision and keep them away from me by the threat were I would be held only for the purpose of making me appear in court with the Commissioner Mr. Graham and the Department of the Interior, and that they would immediately send that it would be useless for me to send any complaints or would come right back to me and I could make up "fix" in the Dept.

If you find it convenient to see Judge Harrill of Regina, show him the whole circumstances of the affair. I feel sure I can be sure that my case will be heard by him and probably by any person of influence of Mr. Wilson.

I feel too do many of my friends that if the details truthfully given in Ottawa could be known, no further oppression would be visited upon me. I have been in the hands of a cruel and unfeeling man so much persecuted.

Perhaps I shall add, in order to show Wilson in his turn that he compelled Miss Grant, the older but shorter woman, to sign a false affidavit—Miss Grant admitted this to me when she first came into my possession. Judge Harrill knew this—and I subsequently wrote it back to Miss Grant with assurance of forgiveness and so that she should be satisfied between us. I was also treated—the spell was broken off it.

Would I be justified for helping the Dept. and itself of this nature?

Am I still a British Subject and have the British idea of right and wrong? Just this—I am in my prime of life now older and capable than are my present helpers, but I am not capable of remaining the unjustly ignored. If I am capable, and convinced with the Warm Memories, Social and Civic.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Yours of 23rd ultimo came to hand by our last weekly mail. I thank you for the information it conveys.

Since the new building will not be ready before June and holidays begin July 15th, I take it you will wish the transfer to be made while the school is closed rather than break in on the work during June. Be good enough to let me know whether the above is in accord with your wishes or if you prefer to close out here when the new School is ready.

My resignation went in some months ago but I agreed to remain until holidays and attend to the moving at this end. Presumably my successor will be on hand to see to the settling in the new building.

Your position re the discharge of pupils is, it seems to me, the only reasonable one.
I have always informed both parents and child that there must be authority from the Department before a boy or girl can be discharged, and that this authority must be asked for in the regular way. From some other sources they have recently got the impression that when 16 years of age they can step out without consulting anyone. Accordingly about a month ago two boys, 16 and 17 respectively, took French leave without any suggestion or discharge either from the boys or their parents. I referred the case to Capt. Edwards who stated that as they were above 16 nothing could be done, and as nothing was done another of 17 years followed their example. It would seem therefore that the guardianship of a Principal becomes in practice a dead letter when a boy or girl reaches 16 years, and I have only to report that Nos. 74, 77 & 78 have discharged themselves. If however you have any instruction or guidance to give me I shall be glad to hear from you.

Dear Madam:

It has been recently brought to our attention that certain charges have been filed against the Principal of the above named School. We, as members of the present Staff, would like to refute the said charges.

We have always found him kind, considerate, and very just, a friendly spirit existing at all times between the Principal and Staff.

We cannot see that the above two charges have anything to do with the Principal, and their use against him seems unreasonable.

6. "I believe she is the real head of the School."

In our experience Mr. Menzies has been the head of the School.
